    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
</div>
				  	 	<div class="grid_8">  <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-areas-of-concentration view-id-areas_of_concentration view-display-id-page view-dom-id-ef4ad3edffa815d78deae4f4e071798f">
        
  
      <div class="attachment attachment-before">
      <div class="view view-areas-of-concentration view-id-areas_of_concentration view-display-id-attachment_1">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">
      
          <p>The Area of Concentration requirement is as follows: <em> Majors will complete an individually articulated area of concentration consisting of a minimum of 20 units of upper-division coursework. The plan for the area of concentration (the application to declare the major) must be approved during the student's sophomore or junior year by an American Studies faculty advisor. </em></p>
<p>The concentration requirement assures that students have reasonable depth and breadth in their American Studies major. The concentrations must include coursework from two or more departments or fields, and must examine a theme, issue, or problem in American culture. Areas of concentration may be highly individualized, depending on the student's personal interest, prior preparation, and the availability of courses.</p>
<p>To the right are examples of how areas of concentration could be formulated for specific American Studies majors.</p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div>    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>

				  	 	</div>			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->
	<div class="clear"></div>

      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">
      
          <h2><a href="/areas-of-concentration/american-folklore-and-folklife" class="active">American Folklore and Folklife</a></h2>    
          <p>"American Folklore and Folklife" allows the student interested in the study of folklore and folklife to examine and analyze traditional expressive culture (<em>e.g.</em>, ethnic, regional, occupational, gender, and other traditional identities) in all its forms.  Examining the historical, cultural, social, and psychological dimensions of such expressive forms as myth, legend, folktale, music, dance, art, belief, foodways, ritual and ceremony, the student investigates how tradition expresses the dynamics of human behavior.</p>
<h3><span>Courses:</span></h3>
<p>Anthropology 121AC - American Material Culture</p>
<p>Anthropology 163AC - American Folklore</p>
<p>Native American Studies 120 - Topics in Native American Arts</p>
<p>Nutritional Science 104 - Human Food Practices</p>
<p>Religious Studies 171AC - Religious Pluralism in America</p>
<p>Theater, Dance and Performance Studies 121 - Performance and Culture</p>
<h3>Alternate Courses:</h3>
<p>American Studies 110 - When topic is “Folklore and American Culture”</p>
<p>Anthropology 122A/B/F/G - Archaeology of the Americas</p>
<p>Anthropology 136B - Museum Methods</p>
<p>Anthropology 160AC - Forms of Folklore</p>
<p>Anthropology 162AC - The Folktale in the Modern World: The Marvelous and the Monstrous</p>
<p>English 133T - When topic is “Orality and Black Literature”</p>
<p>English 166AC - When topic is “Race and Revision in Early America”</p>
<p>Linguistics 151 - Language and Gender</p>
<p>Native American Studies 149 - Gender in Native American Society</p>
<p>Psychology 106 - Psychology of Dreams</p>
<p>Rhetoric 132 - Rhetoric, Culture and Society</p>
<p>Sociology C112/Religious Studies C182 - Sociology of Religion</p>
    
              </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>

      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">
      
          <h2><a href="/areas-of-concentration/american-food-cultures" class="active">American Food Cultures</a></h2>    
          <p class="p1">This area of concentration examines both historic and contemporary social, economic, cultural, and psychological factors that shape food consumption practices. Exploring food systems from production through consumption, the student traces agricultural concerns, examines environmental, ethical, and economic factors in food production and distribution, and investigates the various beliefs, rituals, and behaviors surrounding food in the United States.</p>
<h3>Courses:</h3>
<p class="p1">Anthropology 121AC - American Material Culture</p>
<p class="p1">Environmental Economics and Policy 141 - Agricultural and Environmental Policy</p>
<p class="p1">ESPM C159 - Human Diet</p>
<p class="p1">History 103D - “Food and Eating Practices in the U.S. and Europe Since the 19th Century”</p>
<p class="p1">Nutritional Science 104 - Human Food Practices</p>
<p class="p1">Nutritional Science 135 - Food Systems Organization and Management</p>
<h3>Alternate Courses:</h3>
<p class="p1">American Studies 110 - When topic is “Advertising in America” or “California Foodways”</p>
<p class="p1">Nutritional Science 106 - Introduction to Food Science</p>
<p class="p1">Nutritional Science 166 - Nutrition in the Community</p>
    
              </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>

    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-areas-of-concentration view-id-areas_of_concentration view-display-id-page view-dom-id-5cb996367f5acbfce229becd8eaf3320">

      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">
      
          <h2><a href="/areas-of-concentration/american-popular-culture" class="active">American Popular Culture</a></h2>    
          <p class="p1">This area of concentration examines the creation, production, reception, and consumption of popular/commercial culture in the U.S.</p>
<h3>Courses:</h3>
<p class="p1">African American Studies 142B - The Cross Cultural Images of American Minorities in Film</p>
<p class="p1">American Studies C118 - Topics in Popular Culture</p>
<p class="p1">English 176 - Literature and Popular Culture</p>
<p class="p1">Gender and Women’s Studies 125 - Women and Film</p>
<p class="p1">Native American Studies 158 - Native Americans and the Cinema</p>
<p class="p1">Sociology 160 - Sociology of Culture</p>
<h3>Alternate Courses:</h3>
<p class="p1">African American Studies 142AC - Race and American Film</p>
<p class="p1">American Studies 101 - When topic is “The 1980s”</p>
<p class="p1">American Studies 101 - When topic is “The Atomic Age”</p>
<p class="p1">American Studies 110 - When topic is “Advertising in America”</p>
<p class="p1">American Studies 110 - When topic is “The American Teenager”</p>
<p class="p1">American Studies C125 - American Media and Global Politics</p>
<p class="p1">English 150 When topic is - “Novel to Film Adaptation”</p>
<p class="p1">Film 108 - Film Genre</p>
<p class="p1">History 124b - The Recent United States</p>
<p class="p1">Media Studies 102 - The Effects of Mass Media</p>
<p class="p1">Sociology 180 - American Society</p>
    
              </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>

				  	 	</div>			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->

				  	 	<div class="grid_8">  <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-areas-of-concentration view-id-areas_of_concentration view-display-id-page view-dom-id-27bf4b537ef0dde10a9d03204e11263f">
        
  
      <div class="attachment attachment-before">

      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">
      
          <h2><a href="/areas-of-concentration/american-public-policy-" class="active">American Public Policy </a></h2>    
          <p class="p1">“American Public Policy” investigates the way that social problems are defined and analyzed in the United States, and focuses on the political and historical dimensions of public policy.</p>
<h3>Courses:</h3>
<p class="p1">African American Studies 107 - Race and Public Policy</p>
<p class="p1">Legal Studies 162 - Courts and Social Policy</p>
<p class="p1">Political Science 183 - Administrative Behavior</p>
<p class="p1">Public Policy 101 - Introduction to Public Policy Analysis</p>
<p class="p1">Public Health 150D - Introduction to Health Policy and Management</p>
<p class="p1">Public Policy 170 - Ethics in Public Policy</p>
<h3>Alternate Courses:</h3>
<p class="p1">Asian American Studies - 145 Politics, Public Policy, and Asian American Communities</p>
<p class="p1">Legal Studies C165 - Drug, Tobacco, and Alcohol Policy</p>
<p class="p1">Political Science 189 - Topics in Public Organization and Policy</p>
<p class="p1">Public Policy 103 - Wealth and Poverty</p>
<p class="p1">Public Policy 117AC - Race, Ethnicity, and Public Policy</p>
<p class="p1">Public Policy 184 - The Economics of Public Problem-Solving</p>
<p class="p1">Social Welfare 112 - Social Welfare Policy</p>
    
              </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>

				  	 	</div>			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->
	<div class="clear"></div>
	
<!-- Footer -->
  		<footer>

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Areas of Concentration</h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			  <div class="grid_3">  <div class="region region-left">
    <div id="block-views-areas-of-concentration-block-1" class="block block-views"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-areas-of-concentration view-id-areas_of_concentration view-display-id-block_1 view-dom-id-4d87ed560c5a660639a8ba6430033670">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first">
      
          <a href="/areas-of-concentration/american-folklore-and-folklife">American Folklore and Folklife</a>    </div>
  <div class="views-row views-row-2 views-row-even">
      
          <a href="/areas-of-concentration/american-food-cultures">American Food Cultures</a>    </div>
  <div class="views-row views-row-3 views-row-odd">
      
          <a href="/areas-of-concentration/american-popular-culture">American Popular Culture</a>    </div>
  <div class="views-row views-row-4 views-row-even">
      
          <a href="/areas-of-concentration/american-public-policy-">American Public Policy </a>    </div>
  <div class="views-row views-row-5 views-row-odd">
      
          <a href="/areas-of-concentration/art%2C-architecture%2C-design%2C-and-landscape-in-america">Art, Architecture, Design, and Landscape in America</a>    </div>
  <div class="views-row views-row-6 views-row-even">

    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-areas-of-concentration view-id-areas_of_concentration view-display-id-page view-dom-id-3775db8d016cdd9650da7ede1253fb87">
        
  
      <div class="attachment attachment-before">
      <div class="view view-areas-of-concentration view-id-areas_of_concentration view-display-id-attachment_1">
        
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div>    </div>
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">
      
          <h2><a href="/areas-of-concentration/art%2C-architecture%2C-design%2C-and-landscape-in-america" class="active">Art, Architecture, Design, and Landscape in America</a></h2>    
          <p class="p1">Looking at buildings, artworks, objects of all kinds for social content and cultural meaning, this concentration draws on the resources of many departments. Focusing on physical objects designed and made by artisans, artists, professional designers, vernacular builders, housewives and others, students concentrate on analyzing the historical, rhetorical, and cultural as well as functional aspects of the human-made material world. Taking foundational/lower division courses as required in several of the listed disciplines, students will design their major drawing on these and other (approved) offerings.</p>
<h3><span>Courses:</span></h3>
<p class="p1">Anthropology 121A/AC - American Material Culture</p>
<p class="p1">Architecture 174C - San Francisco Architecture</p>
<p class="p1">Art History 185A - American Art (1800-present)</p>
<p class="p1">Art History C189 - The American Forest: Its Ecology, History, and Representation</p>
<p class="p1">Geography 125 - The American City</p>
<p class="p1">Landscape Architecture 170 - History and Literature of Landscape Architecture</p>
<h3>Alternate Courses:</h3>
<p class="p1">American Studies C111A - Architecture in Depression and War</p>
<p class="p1">American Studies 110 - When topic is “Advertising in America”</p>
<p class="p1">Anthropology 122A - Archaeology of North America</p>
<p class="p1">Anthropology 148 - Anthropology of the Environment</p>
<p class="p1">Architecture 118 - Housing American Cultures</p>
<p class="p1">Art History 185B - American Architecture: Domestic Forms</p>
<p class="p1">City Planning 111 - Introduction to Housing</p>
<p class="p1">City Planning 140 - Urban Design: City-Building and Place-Making</p>
<p class="p1">Environmental Design C169A - American Cultural Landscapes, 1600 to 1900</p>
<p class="p1">Environmental Design C169B - American Cultural Landscapes, 1900 to Present</p>
<p class="p1">Geography 181 - Urban Field Study</p>
<p class="p1">History 120AC - American Environmental and Cultural History</p>
<p class="p1">Landscape Architecture 141AC - American Landscape: Multicultural Difference &amp; Diversity</p>
<p class="p1">Landscape Architecture C171 - The American Designed Landscape since 1850</p>
    
              </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>

				  	 	</div>			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->
	<div class="clear"></div>

      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">
      
          <h2><a href="/areas-of-concentration/computer-science-and-the-american-public" class="active">Computer Science and the American Public</a></h2>    
          <p class="p1">The sequence below assumes interest in the cultural meaning of computer design and the social construction of American engineering education: an investigation of the ways in which computer design is formed and changed in a social context. N.B. For advanced technical courses, the student would need rigorous preparation in mathematics, physics, and computer science. For instance, the student might be an undergraduate engineering student who transferred to American Studies in his or her junior year. In some cases, non-engineering students might negotiate permission to take such courses (*) on a P/NP basis.</p>
<h3>Courses:</h3>
<p class="p1">American Studies 102 - When topic is “Digital Neighborhoods”</p>
<p class="p1">American Studies C134 - Information Technology and Society</p>
<p class="p1">EECS 195 - Social Implications of Computer Technology</p>
<p class="p1">Interdepartmental Studies 100AC - Technology and the American Experience</p>
<p class="p1">Interdisciplinary Studies 100D - Introduction to Technology, Society, and Culture</p>
<p class="p1">Political Science 138D - Governance of the E-conomy</p>
<h3>Alternate Courses:</h3>
<p class="p1">EECS 150* - Components and Design Techniques for Digital Systems</p>
<p class="p1">EECS 152* - Computer Architecture and Engineering</p>
<p class="p1">EECS C182 - The Neural Basis of Thought and Language</p>
    
              </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>

      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">
      
          <h2><a href="/areas-of-concentration/disability-studies-" class="active">Disability Studies </a></h2>    
          <p class="p1">“Disability Studies” directs its focus toward how society creates “disability” by constructing identities and barriers.</p>
<h3><span>Courses:</span></h3>
<p class="p1">Anthropology 115 - Introduction to Medical Anthropology</p>
<p class="p1">English 175 - Literature and Disability</p>
<p class="p1">Public Health 130AC - Aging, Health, and Diversity</p>
<p class="p1">Sociology 155 - Sociology of Illness and Medicine</p>
<p class="p1">UGIS 110 - Introduction to Disability Studies</p>
<p class="p1">UGIS 112 - Women and Disability</p>
<h3>Alternate Courses:</h3>
<p class="p1">Anthropology 119 - Special Topics in Medical Anthropology</p>
<p class="p1">Chicano Studies 176 - Chicanos and Health Care</p>
<p class="p1">City and Regional Planning 120 - Community Planning and Public Policy for Disability</p>
<p class="p1">Economics 157 - Health Economics</p>
<p class="p1">Landscape Architecture 140 - Social and Psychological Factors in Open Space Design</p>
<p class="p1">UGIS 116 - Disability, Identity, and Social Movements</p>
    
              </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>

				  	 	</div>			  </div>
		  </div>

      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">
      
          <h2><a href="/areas-of-concentration/education-in-america" class="active">Education in America</a></h2>    
          <p class="p1">This area of concentration explores the history, policy implications, and practices of education in the United States.</p>
<h3>Courses:</h3>
<p class="p1">American Studies 110 - When topic is “Schooling in America”</p>
<p class="p1">Asian American Studies 146 - Asian Americans and Education</p>
<p class="p1">Chicano Studies 172 - Chicanos and the Educational System</p>
<p class="p1">Education 140AC - Literacy: Individual and Societal Development</p>
<p class="p1">Education 189 - Democracy and Education</p>
<p class="p1">Sociology 113 - Sociology of Education</p>
<h3>Alternate Courses:</h3>
<p class="p1">Education 185 - Gender and Education in the Americas</p>
<p class="p1">Education 190 - Current Issues in Education</p>
<p class="p1">Education 190B - Unraveling Education: A Participatory Inquiry</p>
    
              </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>

				  	 	</div>			  </div>

      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">
      
          <h2><a href="/areas-of-concentration/healthcare-in-american-culture-since-1945" class="active">Healthcare in American Culture Since 1945</a></h2>    
          <p class="p1">This area of concentration explores American attitudes about healthcare and the development of institutions for healthcare. N.B. For entry into some of these courses, the student may need to take preparatory lower-division coursework.</p>
<h3>Courses:</h3>
<p class="p1">Anthropology 115 - Introduction to Medical Anthropology</p>
<p class="p1">Chicano Studies 176 - Chicanos and Health Care</p>
<p class="p1">Economics 157 - Health Economics</p>
<p class="p1">Public Health 113 - Campus/Community Health Impact Program</p>
<p class="p1">Public Health 131AC - Race, Ethnicity, and Health in America</p>
<p class="p1">Sociology 155 - Sociology of Illness and Medicine</p>
<h3>Alternate Courses:</h3>
<p class="p1">Anthropology 114 - History of Anthropological Thought</p>
<p class="p1">Nutritional Science 166 - Nutrition in the Community</p>
<p class="p1">Public Health 103 - Drugs, Healthy, and Society</p>
<p class="p1">Sociology 110 - Organizations and Institutions</p>
<p class="p1">Sociology 150 - Social Psychology</p>
    
              </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>

				  	 	</div>			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->
	<div class="clear"></div>

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Areas of Concentration</h2>

      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">
      
          <h2><a href="/areas-of-concentration/nature-in-america" class="active">Nature in America</a></h2>    
          <p class="p1">“Nature in America” explores the historical, social, ideological, scientific, economic, and geographic dimensions of the natural environment in the United States. The student choosing this area of concentration studies the interaction of natural systems and social contexts over time.</p>
<h3>Courses:</h3>
<p class="p1">Anthropology 148 - Anthropology of the Environment</p>
<p class="p1">Art History C189 - The American Forest: Its Ecology, History, and Representation</p>
<p class="p1">Art History 185A - American Art (1800-present)</p>
<p class="p1">English 130B - American Literature: 1800-1865</p>
<p class="p1">ESPM 161 - Environmental Philosophy and Ethic</p>
<p class="p1">History 120AC - American Environmental and Cultural History</p>
<h3>Alternate Courses:</h3>
<p class="p1">Anthropology 129D - The Archaeology of Global Change</p>
<p class="p1">Environmental Economics and Policy C102 - Natural Resource Economics</p>
<p class="p1">Environmental Economics and Policy 131 - Globalization and the Natural Environment</p>
<p class="p1">Environmental Economics and Policy 162 - Economics of Water Resources</p>
<p class="p1">Environmental Economics and Policy C180 - Ecological Economics in Historical Context</p>
<p class="p1">ESPM 102C - Resource Management</p>
<p class="p1">ESPM 102D - Resource and Environmental Policy</p>
<p class="p1">ESPM 116B - Range Ecology, Improvements, and Management</p>
<p class="p1">ESPM 117 - Urban Garden Ecosystems</p>
<p class="p1">ESPM 160AC - American Environmental and Cultural History</p>
<p class="p1">Geography 134 - Natural Hazards and Problems</p>
<p class="p1">History 126B - The American West</p>
<p class="p1">History 127AC - California</p>
<p class="p1">Landscape Architecture 110 - Ecological Analysis</p>
    
              </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>

          <h2><a href="/areas-of-concentration/other-possible-areas-of-concentration-" class="active">Other Possible Areas of Concentration </a></h2>    
          <p class="p1">American Class Structures</p>
<p class="p1">American People and Places</p>
<p class="p1">American Warfare</p>
<p class="p1">Childhood in America</p>
<p class="p1">Housing, Community and Economic Development in the U.S.</p>
<p class="p1">Identity and Representation in the U.S.</p>
<p class="p1">Individual Learning and Education Psychology</p>
<p class="p1">U.S. Social Movements</p>
    
              </div>

      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">
      
          <h2><a href="/areas-of-concentration/politics-and-american-communities-" class="active">Politics and American Communities </a></h2>    
          <p class="p1">This area of concentration examines the interplay between social groups and power, inequality and social justice in the United States.</p>
<h3>Courses:</h3>
<p class="p1">African American Studies 121 - Black Political Life in the United States</p>
<p class="p1">Anthropology 139 - Controlling Processes</p>
<p class="p1">Peace and Conflict Studies 128AC - Human Rights and American Cultures</p>
<p class="p1">Philosophy 113AC - Philosophical Perspectives on Race and Culture</p>
<p class="p1">Political Science 111AC - The Politics of Displacement</p>
<p class="p1">Political Science 138F - Immigrants, Citizenship, and the State</p>
<h3>Alternate Courses:</h3>
<p class="p1">African American Studies 124 - Political Philosophy of Martin Luther King, Jr.</p>
<p class="p1">African American Studies 125 - History of the Civil Rights Movement</p>
<p class="p1">African American Studies 138 - Black Nationalism</p>
<p class="p1">Asian American Studies 125 - Contemporary Issues of Southeast Asian Refugees in the U.S.</p>
<p class="p1">Asian American Studies 126 - Southeast Asian Migration &amp; Community Formation</p>
<p class="p1">Asian American Studies 141 - Law in the Asian American Community</p>
<p class="p1">Chicano Studies 110 - Latina/o Philosophy and Religious Thought</p>
<p class="p1">Legal Studies 160 - Punishment, Culture, and Society</p>
<p class="p1">Native American Studies 100 - Native American Law</p>
<p class="p1">Native American Studies 101 - Native American Tribal Governments</p>
<p class="p1">Peace and Conflict Studies 154AC - Multicultural Conflict Resolution</p>
<p class="p1">Political Science 176 - The Unseen America</p>
<p class="p1">UGIS 116 - Disability, Identity, and Social Movements</p>
    
              </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>

				  	 	</div>			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->

    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-areas-of-concentration view-id-areas_of_concentration view-display-id-page view-dom-id-2c450657de2711cd5e389a5ed26fa7d4">
        
  
      <div class="attachment attachment-before">

      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">
      
          <h2><a href="/areas-of-concentration/race%2C-ethnicity%2C-and-nation" class="active">Race, Ethnicity, and Nation</a></h2>    
          <p class="p1">Focusing on the history of encounters between the various peoples who comprise the American nation, this area of concentration exploresthe migrations, settlements, contacts, contests, and exchanges that have shaped the cultural, political, social, and economic construction of the United States.</p>
<h3>Courses:</h3>
<p class="p1">African American Studies 116 - Slavery and American Life Before 1865</p>
<p class="p1">Anthropology 122B - Culture Contact in North America</p>
<p class="p1">Demography 145AC - The American Immigrant Experience</p>
<p class="p1">Geography 159AC - The Southern Border</p>
<p class="p1">Linguistics 155AC - Native American Meets the Europeans</p>
<p class="p1">Political Science 118AC - Three American Cultures</p>
<h3>Alternate Courses:</h3>
<p class="p1">African American Studies 109 - Black and Male in American Life</p>
<p class="p1">African American Studies 111 - Race, Class, and Gender in the United States</p>
<p class="p1">African American Studies 117 - African Americans in the Industrial Age, 1865-1970</p>
<p class="p1">Anthropology 124AC - Hawaiian Ethnohistory</p>
<p class="p1">Asian American Studies 121 - Chinese American History</p>
<p class="p1">Asian American Studies 122 - Japanese American History</p>
<p class="p1">Asian American Studies 123 - Korean American History</p>
<p class="p1">Asian American Studies 124 - Filipino American History</p>
<p class="p1">Chicano Studies 150A - History of the Southwest: Spanish and Mexican Period</p>
<p class="p1">Chicano Studies 150B - History of the Southwest: Mexican-United States War to Present</p>
<p class="p1">Chicano Studies 159 - Mexican Immigration</p>
<p class="p1">Ethnic Studies 135AC - Contemporary U.S. Immigration</p>
<p class="p1">Ethnic Studies 136 - Immigrant Women</p>
<p class="p1">Ethnic Studies 147 - Women of Color in the United States</p>
<p class="p1">Ethnic Studies 150AC - People of Mixed Racial Descent</p>
<p class="p1">History 122AC - Antebellum America: The Advent of Mass Society</p>
<p class="p1">History 123 - Civil War and Reconstruction</p>
<p class="p1">History 126B - The West in United States History</p>
<p class="p1">History 125 - History of African Americans and Race Relations in the United States</p>
<p class="p1">History 137AC - The Repeopling of America</p>
<p class="p1">Native American Studies 175 - History of Native Americans in California</p>
<p class="p1">Rhetoric 152AC - Race and Order in the New Republic</p>
    
              </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>

		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Areas of Concentration</h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			  <div class="grid_3">  <div class="region region-left">
    <div id="block-views-areas-of-concentration-block-1" class="block block-views"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-areas-of-concentration view-id-areas_of_concentration view-display-id-block_1 view-dom-id-4d87ed560c5a660639a8ba6430033670">

      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">
      
          <h2><a href="/areas-of-concentration/the-american-city%3A-urban-structures-and-cultures" class="active">The American City: Urban Structures and Cultures</a></h2>    
          <h3>Courses:</h3>
<p>City and Regional Planning 110 Introduction to City Planning<br />City and Regional Planning 118AC The Urban Community<br />Geography 125 The American City<br />Geography 181 Urban Field Study<br />History 134A/B The Age of the City<br />Sociology 125AC Urban Sociology</p>
<h3>Alternate Courses:</h3>
<p>African American Studies 137 Multicultural Communities<br />American Studies 102 When topic is New Orleans<br />American Studies 102 When topic is San Francisco and Los Angeles<br />Architecture 170A/B An Historical Survey of Architecture &amp; Urbanism<br />Architecture 174AC San Francisco Architecture<br />City and Regional Planning 113B Community Economic Development<br />Environmental Design 100 The City: Theories &amp; Methods in Urban Studies<br />Environmental Design 169A/B American Cultural Landscapes</p>
    
              </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>

				  	 	</div>			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->
	<div class="clear"></div>

      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">
      
          <h2><a href="/areas-of-concentration/the-american-family" class="active">The American Family</a></h2>    
          <p>This area of concentration focuses on the history, changing structure and meaning of the family in American society.</p>
<h3>Courses:</h3>
<p>African American Studies 122<br />African American Families in American Society<br />Chicano Studies 179<br />Chicana/o Families<br />History C129<br />Children Through History: Social Practices and Social Welfare<br />Legal Studies 155<br />Government and the Family<br />Public Policy C164<br />Impact of Government Policies on Poor Children and Families<br />Sociology 111<br />Sociology of the Family</p>
<h3>Alternate Courses:</h3>
<p>Asian American Studies 150<br />Gender and Generation in Asian American Families<br />Demography C126<br />Social Consequences of Population Dynamics<br />Demography C165<br />Family and Household in Comparative Perspective<br />Gender and Women's Studies 120<br />The History of American Women<br />History 131<br />Social History of the United States<br />Psychology 131<br />Developmental Psychopathology</p>
    
              </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>

				  	 	</div>			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->
	<div class="clear"></div>

      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">
      
          <h2><a href="/areas-of-concentration/the-global-united-states" class="active">The Global United States</a></h2>    
          <p class="p1">This area of concentration explores the role of the United States outside of its national borders, focusing on both U.S. foreign policy and the flow of American peoples, ideas, and goods throughout the world.</p>
<h3>Courses:</h3>
<p class="p1">Asian American Studies 130 - Asian Americans and Foreign Policy</p>
<p class="p1">Environmental Economics and Policy 131 - Globalization and the Natural Environment</p>
<p class="p1">History 128 - Liberal Superpower: Reform and Political Economy in Postwar U.S. History</p>
<p class="p1">Peace and Conflict Studies 149 - Global Change and World Order</p>
<p class="p1">Political Science 126A - International Political Economy</p>
<p class="p1">Political Science 138G - National Success and Failure in the Age of a Global Economy</p>
<h3>Alternate Courses:</h3>
<p class="p1">Business Administration 178 - Introduction to International Business</p>
<p class="p1">Chicano Studies 165 - Cuba, the United States and Cuban Americans</p>
<p class="p1">Ethnic Studies C173 - Cultures of U.S. Imperialism: Spanish-American War of 1898</p>
<p class="p1">Military Officers’ Education Program 145 - National Security Forces in Contemporary American Society</p>
<p class="p1">Peace and Conflict Studies 119 - Topics in Peace and Conflict Issues</p>
<p class="p1">Peace and Conflict Studies 127 - Human Rights and Global Politics</p>
<p class="p1">Political Science 124A - War!</p>
<p class="p1">Political Science 127A - International Law</p>
<p class="p1">PEIS 150 - Advanced Study in Political Economy of Industrial Society</p>
    
              </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>

				  	 	</div>			  </div>

      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">
      
          <h2><a href="/areas-of-concentration/visual%2C-literary%2C-and-performance-cultures-" class="active">Visual, Literary, and Performance Cultures </a></h2>    
          <p class="p1">This area of concentration explores American consumer culture in relation to literature and performance.</p>
<h3>Courses:</h3>
<p class="p1">African American Studies 144 - Black Visual Culture</p>
<p class="p1">American Studies C174 - Visual Autobiography</p>
<p class="p1">English C136 - When topic is “Consumer Culture in Post-Civil War America”</p>
<p class="p1">Rhetoric 139AC - Autobiography and American Individualism</p>
<p class="p1">Theater 119 - Performance Theory: Asian/American Performance Across Media</p>
<p class="p1">Theater 121 - Performance and Culture - Performance and Television</p>
<h3>Alternate Courses:</h3>
<p class="p1">African American Studies 150B - African American Literature 1920 to Present</p>
<p class="p1">African American Studies C151A - African American Plays from 1858 to 1959</p>
<p class="p1">African American Studies C151B - Contemporary African American Drama</p>
<p class="p1">Asian American Studies 171 - Asian Americans in Film and Video</p>
<p class="p1">Asian American Studies 172 - Asian American Literature</p>
<p class="p1">Gender and Women’s Studies C153B - Contemporary Images of African American Women in Literature</p>
<p class="p1">Music 130A/B/BM - African American Music</p>
<p class="p1">Music 174F - Studies in African American Music</p>
<p class="p1">Native American Studies 152 - Native American Literature</p>
<p class="p1">Native American Studies 158 - Native Americans and the Cinema</p>
<p class="p1">Native American Studies 182 - Native American Music</p>
<p class="p1">Theater C132 - African American Dramatic Literature</p>
    
              </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>

				  	 	</div>			  </div>

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Fall Courses</h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-views-courses-new-block-1" class="block block-views"><div class="widget bottom">    <div class="view-content">
        <span class="views-summary views-summary-unformatted">        <a href="/courses/fall/place-courses">Place Courses</a>
          (4)
      </span>  <span class="views-summary views-summary-unformatted">        <a href="/courses/fall/introductory-courses">Introductory Courses</a>
          (3)
      </span>  <span class="views-summary views-summary-unformatted">        <a href="/courses/fall/senior-thesis-seminars">Senior Thesis Seminars</a>
          (3)
      </span>  <span class="views-summary views-summary-unformatted">        <a href="/courses/fall/time-courses">Time Courses</a>
          (2)
      </span>  <span class="views-summary views-summary-unformatted">        <a href="/courses/fall/special-courses-of-interest">Special Courses of Interest</a>
          (1)
      </span>  <span class="views-summary views-summary-unformatted">        <a href="/courses/fall/honors-seminar">Honors Seminar</a>
          (1)
      </span>  <span class="views-summary views-summary-unformatted">        <a href="/courses/fall/lower-division-courses-of-interest">Lower Division Courses of Interest</a>
          (1)
      </span>    </div>
  </div><div class="clear"></div></div><div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-courses-new view-id-courses_new view-display-id-page_2 view-dom-id-76216426b70f28576d3ab4a322f4207a">
            <div class="view-header">
      Displaying Courses 1 - 15 of 15 | <a href="/courses/fall">Reset Filters</a>    </div>
  
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
      <div class="view-grouping"><div class="view-grouping-header">Fall 2017</div><div class="view-grouping-content">  <h3>Introductory Courses</h3>
  <div class="groupers">
    <div id="courses-dave-template" class="grid_12">
	<div class="course_title_div">
		<span class="bolded">
	African American Studies 27 AC</span> Lives of Struggle: Minorities in Majority Culture	 </div>



<div class="body"><div class="course_logistics"><ul><li class="li-time">TTh 12:30-2</li><li class="li-instructor">M. Cohen</li><li class="li-location">145 Dwinelle</li><li class="li-units">3 Units</li><li class="li-cc">Class Number: 12321</li></ul></div><div class="sections">Sections -TO BE DETERMINED</div><div class="expandable2"><p>IN FALL 2017, THIS COURSE SATISFIES THE AMERICAN STUDIES 10 REQUIREMENT. The purpose of this course is to examine the many forms that the struggle of minorities can assume. The focus is on individual struggle and its outcome as reported and perceived by the individuals themselves. Members of three minority aggregates are considered: African Americans, Asian Americans (so called), and Chicano/Latino Americans. The choice of these three has to do with the different histories of members of these aggregrates. Such differences have produced somewhat different approaches to struggle.</p>
</div></div>


</div>
<div class="clear"></div>







  </div>
  <div class="groupers">
    <div id="courses-dave-template" class="grid_12">
	<div class="course_title_div">
		<span class="bolded">
	American Studies 10</span> Food Culture in America	 </div>



<div class="body"><div class="course_logistics"><ul><li class="li-time">TTh 11-12:30</li><li class="li-instructor">K. Moran, M. Lovell</li><li class="li-location">3 LeConte</li><li class="li-units">4 Units</li><li class="li-cc">Class Number: 22204</li></ul></div><div class="sections">Section 201                                         M 3-4, 115 Kroeber<br />
Section 202                                         M 12-1, 238 Kroeber<br />
Section 203                                         M 2-3, 238 Kroeber<br />
Section 204                                        M 1-2, 106 Wheeler</div><div class="expandable2"><p>This course will introduce students to the interdisciplinary field of American Studies, taking “Food” as its central theme. We will explore the social history, political economy and "aesthetics" of eating and cooking in America.  Specific topics will include the development and importance of New World agriculture, the design of shopping and eating spaces, eco history, the objects we use in the kitchen, the use of food as a metaphor in literature and in popular culture, food service workers, ethnic foods, food advertising, food photography, fast food, the “slow” food movement, and food biographies. We will also consider the specific food culture of Berkeley, and explore the rise of the so-called Berkeley "gourmet ghetto."</p>
<p> Course Goals:  This course is meant to enable you to think and do research as an interdisciplinary scholar, specifically to give you the tools to do readings of a literary text, a painting, a common object, a film, a space.  You will also learn the basics of conducting an interview, drawing a floorplan, recording and analyzing behaviors.  You will practice historical research—gathering and evaluating evidence--as well as practice the skills involved in finding a thesis and arguing it persuasively.  </p>
</div></div>


</div>
<div class="clear"></div>







  </div>
  <div class="groupers">
    <div id="courses-dave-template" class="grid_12">
	<div class="course_title_div">
		<span class="bolded">
	Letters and Science 40 C</span> Hollywood: The Place, the Fantasy, and the Industry	 </div>



<div class="body"><div class="course_logistics"><ul><li class="li-time">MW 12-2</li><li class="li-instructor">K. Moran</li><li class="li-location">141 McCone</li><li class="li-units">4 Units</li><li class="li-cc">Class Number: 44495</li></ul></div><div class="sections">Section 101 - M 9-10, 110 Barker<br />
Section 102 - Th 9-10, 115 Kroeber<br />
Section 103 - Th 2-3, 106 Dwinelle<br />
Section 104 - M 10-11, 115 Kroeber</div><div class="expandable2"><p><span>IN FALL 2017, THIS COURSE SATISFIES THE AMERICAN STUDIES 10 REQUIREMENT. This course is about the history of the Hollywood "Dream Factory," focusing on both parts of that phrase. We will examine the historical and geographical development of the motion picture industry from the rise of the studio system to the "new" entertainment economy of the 1980's, as we think about the way films have constructed powerful and productive fantasies about the boundaries between public and private, work and play, commerce and art, fantasy and reality.  Our topics will include the history of labor in the culture industry, the implications of shifts in the spatial organization of film production, and the effects of Hollywood on the larger politics of southern California.  We will also discuss the way Hollywood has framed its own history by viewing a number of "movies about movies," including Sullivan's Travels, Singin' in the Rain, Sunset Boulevard, and The Player</span></p>
</div></div>


</div>
<div class="clear"></div>







  </div>
  <h3>Time Courses</h3>
  <div class="groupers">
    <div id="courses-dave-template" class="grid_12">
	<div class="course_title_div">
		<span class="bolded">
	American Studies 101</span> The Harlem Renaissance	 </div>



<div class="body"><div class="course_logistics"><ul><li class="li-time">TTh 11-12:30</li><li class="li-instructor">C. Palmer</li><li class="li-location">20 Barrows</li><li class="li-units">4 Units</li><li class="li-cc">Class Number: 12339</li></ul></div><div class="expandable2"><p>This course explores the social, cultural, political, and personal awakenings in the literature, art, and music of the Negro Renaissance or the New Negro Movement, known as the Harlem Renaissance.  This is remembered as a time (roughly 1918-1930) when, in the midst of legal segregation and increasing anti-Black mob violence, Black American writers, artists, philosophers, activists, and musicians, congregating in New York City’s Harlem, reclaimed the right to represent themselves in a wide range of artistic forms and activist movements.  This course will focus on the forces that led to this "renaissance" as well as those that fueled it.  Primary texts for this course may include Jean Toomer, <em>Cane</em>; Zora Neale Hurston, <em>Their Eyes Were Watching God</em>; George Schuyler, <em>Black No More</em>; Nella Larsen, <em>Passing</em>; poetry by Langston Hughes; and works by Claude McKay, Alain Locke, Jessie Fauset, W.E.B. Du Bois, James Weldon Johnson, Anne Spencer, Alice Dunbar-Nelson, Augusta Savage, Duke Ellington, and others.</p>
</div></div>


</div>
<div class="clear"></div>







  </div>
  <div class="groupers">
    <div id="courses-dave-template" class="grid_12">
	<div class="course_title_div">
		<span class="bolded">
	American Studies 101 AC</span> World War II	 </div>



<div class="body"><div class="course_logistics"><ul><li class="li-time">MW 12-2</li><li class="li-instructor">M. Cohen</li><li class="li-location">160 Kroeber</li><li class="li-units">4 Units</li><li class="li-cc">Class Number: 67505</li></ul></div><div class="expandable2"><p>Linking the battlefields of Europe and Asia to the factories and movie theaters of San Francisco and New York City, this course takes up the cultural and social history of World War II (1931-1945).  World War II was the most destructive war in the history of humanity, killing some 60-80 million people.  It also shattered the old European colonial order and transformed the US into the most powerful country in the world.  The war remains the source of our deepest fears of genocide and nuclear annihilation.  Yet Americans believe World War II to be “The Good War” and we revere its heroes as “The Greatest Generation.”  This class takes a global approach to WWII by focusing on three primary combatants: Nazi Germany, Imperial Japan and the United States.  Consequently, this course focuses explicitly on the role of race and racism in the origins and conduct of the war.   As an American Studies class, we take an interdisciplinary approach to history, reading a range of original sources from propaganda cartoons to oral histories, war photography to experimental fiction.  So what was this war? What did Americans see and do there? And what did that doing do to us?  </p>
</div></div>


</div>
<div class="clear"></div>







  </div>
  <h3>Place Courses</h3>
  <div class="groupers">
    <div id="courses-dave-template" class="grid_12">
	<div class="course_title_div">
		<span class="bolded">
	American Studies 102</span> California, the West, and the World: From Gold and Guano to Google and the New Gilded Age 	 </div>



<div class="body"><div class="course_logistics"><ul><li class="li-time">TTh 9:30-11</li><li class="li-instructor">M. Brilliant</li><li class="li-location">2060 VLSB</li><li class="li-units">4 Units</li><li class="li-cc">Class Number: 12350</li></ul></div><div class="cross-listed">Room-shared with History 128AC</div><div class="expandable2"><p> This course surveys the history of California and the American West from the mid-nineteenth century to the dawn of the twenty-first century. It will situate this state and regional history within the relevant currents of global history, which have profoundly shaped and been shaped by California and the American West. We will pay particular heed to those elements of Californian and western history that are typically associated with the state’s and region’s distinctiveness as a shifting region on the national map, potent and protean symbol in the national (and, often, international) imagination, and catalyst of world historical developments from the Gold Rush and the global guano trade it sparked in the mid-nineteenth century, to the rise of Hollywood in the early twentieth century, to the development and deployment of atomic weapons in the mid-twentieth century, to the emergence of Silicon Valley technological innovation and New Gilded Age income polarization in the late twentieth and early twenty-first centuries.</p>
</div></div>


</div>
<div class="clear"></div>







  </div>
  <div class="groupers">
    <div id="courses-dave-template" class="grid_12">
	<div class="course_title_div">
		<span class="bolded">
	American Studies 102</span> Writing on the Walls	 </div>



<div class="body"><div class="course_logistics"><ul><li class="li-time">F 9-12</li><li class="li-instructor">A. Shanken</li><li class="li-location">270 Wurster</li><li class="li-units">4 Units</li><li class="li-cc">Class Number: 46611</li></ul></div><div class="cross-listed">Cross-listed with Architecture 179</div><div class="expandable2"><div dir="ltr">
<p>SEMINAR COURSE -- PERMISSION OF FACULTY ADVISOR OR INSTRUCTOR IS REQUIRED TO ENROLL.</p>
<p><span style="font-family: georgia, serif;"><span>We all pass by ugly buildings everyday, often in silent, unconscious protest, or register beautiful ones fleetingly, alas, through a windshield. This turning away leaves us unprepared to judge, and more importantly, to demand better. Yet architecture is the most public of <span class="m_-745213645787410804gmail-il">arts</span>. We all use it everyday and this makes us all arbiters of it. The course aims to empower students to seek out their own critical voice<span class="m_-745213645787410804gmail-m_1859092182280751581gmail-msoIns"><ins datetime="2015-11-18T08:35">s</ins></span> in <span class="m_-745213645787410804gmail-il">writing</span> about their surroundings. It will help students sharpen their eye and to show them how to lay out plainly, but with sophistication, the ramifications of various kinds of interventions in the built environment. The campus will be the course's quarry. Students will tour Berkeley's buildings and landscape and read them against bo</span></span><span>th architectural criticism and essays by authors such as </span><span>John McPhee, John Updike, Christopher Hitchens, Sue Allison, Wendell Berry, and Patricia Hampl. </span></p>
</div>
</div></div>


</div>
<div class="clear"></div>







  </div>
  <div class="groupers">
    <div id="courses-dave-template" class="grid_12">
	<div class="course_title_div">
		<span class="bolded">
	American Studies C 111 E</span> New Orleans	 </div>



<div class="body"><div class="course_logistics"><ul><li class="li-time">TTh 2:30-3</li><li class="li-instructor">B. Wagner</li><li class="li-location">140 Barrows</li><li class="li-units">4 Units</li><li class="li-cc">Class Number: 46298</li></ul></div><div class="cross-listed">Cross-listed with English C136</div><div class="expandable2"><p> We will consider the representation of New Orleans in four related formats: (1) historical monograph, (2) folklore collection, (3) jazz autobiography, and (4) cinematic documentary. Our premise is that New Orleans is stranger than fiction. Weekly writing, two essays, two midterm exams, final exam.</p>
</div></div>


</div>
<div class="clear"></div>







  </div>
  <div class="groupers">
    <div id="courses-dave-template" class="grid_12">
	<div class="course_title_div">
		<span class="bolded">
	American Studies C 171</span> The American Designed Landscape since 1850	 </div>



<div class="body"><div class="course_logistics"><ul><li class="li-time">TTh 2-330</li><li class="li-instructor">L. Mozingo</li><li class="li-location">88 Dwinelle</li><li class="li-units">3 Units</li><li class="li-cc">Class Number: 12404</li></ul></div><div class="cross-listed">Cross-listed with Landscape Architecture C171</div><div class="expandable2"><p>This course surveys the history of American landscape architecture since 1850 including the rise of the public parks movement, the development of park systems, the establishment of the national parks, the landscape of the Progressive Era, suburbs, and the modernist landscape.  The survey encompasses urban open spaces, conservation landscapes, urban design, environmental planning, and gardens.  It reviews the cultural and social contexts which have shaped and informed landscape architecture in the United States since the advent of the public parks movement, as well as the aesthetic precepts, environmental concerns, horticultural practices, and technological innovations of American landscapes.</p>
</div></div>


</div>
<div class="clear"></div>







  </div>

<div class="no-body"><div class="course_logistics"><ul><li class="li-time">M 2-4</li><li class="li-instructor">J. Walker</li><li class="li-location">262 Dwinelle</li><li class="li-units">4</li><li class="li-cc">Class Number: 12392</li></ul></div></div>

	American Studies  H 195</span> Senior Honors Thesis Seminar	 </div>



<div class="body"><div class="course_logistics"><ul><li class="li-time">Tu 8-10</li><li class="li-instructor">C. Palmer</li><li class="li-location">115 Kroeber</li><li class="li-units">4 Units</li><li class="li-cc">Class Number: See Faculty Advisor</li></ul></div><div class="expandable2"><p>***NOTE: In order to receive honors in American Studies, a student must have an overall GPA of 3.51, and a GPA of 3.65 for all courses taken in completion of the major (upper and lower division).   Students should discuss with their major faculty adviser the preparation of a bibliography and a brief description of their proposed honors thesis and their eligibility to enroll in honors, based on GPA, the semester <strong>before </strong>they plan to enroll in H195.  They also must secure a faculty adviser from an appropriate field who will agree to direct the honors thesis (the "honors thesis adviser").  THE FACULTY ADVISER’S AGREEMENT MUST BE SUBMITTED TO COURSE INSTRUCTOR NO <strong>LATER THAN THE 2ND WEEK</strong> OF CLASSES.  </p>

  </div>
  <h3>Honors Seminar</h3>
  <div class="groupers">
    <div id="courses-dave-template" class="grid_12">
	<div class="course_title_div">
		<span class="bolded">
	American Studies H 110</span> From SFMOMA to Ghost Ship: Exploring Bay Area Art Ecosystems	 </div>



<div class="body"><div class="course_logistics"><ul><li class="li-time">F 2-5</li><li class="li-instructor">J. Winet</li><li class="li-location">425 Doe</li><li class="li-units">4 Units</li><li class="li-cc">Class Number: 46190</li></ul></div><div class="expandable2"><div dir="ltr">
<p>THIS IS AN HONORS SEMINAR. PERMISSION OF FACULTY ADVISOR OR INSTRUCTOR IS REQUIRED TO ENROLL.</p>
<div><span style="color: #45818e;"> </span></div>
<div><span style="color: #45818e;" data-mce-mark="1">The Bay Area is home to a vibrant and diverse art scene, fueled by thousands of creative artists working in a wide range of media – and with an impressive array of interests. At the same time local and national pressures present formidable challenges to artists. This course will explore the range of environments artists inhabit and animate. </span></div>
<div><span style="color: #45818e;"> </span></div>
<div><span style="color: #45818e;">Working collaboratively, students will conduct public digital humanities research creating online multimedia mobile websites that highlight artist-centered organizations vital to the Area’s culture. Hands-on technical demonstrations and workshops will focus on audio, video and photography production using smart phones. Central to the class will be discussion of best practices for engagement – including the art and craft of interviews and approaches to documentary. </span></div>
<div><span style="color: #45818e;"> </span></div>
<div><span style="color: #45818e;">Seminar activities will include reading and writing assignments, media screenings, field trips to artists’ organizations, artist studios, museums and galleries, and in-class and on-site presentations by arts activists and civic leaders.</span></div>
<div><span style="color: #45818e;"> </span></div>
<div><span style="color: #45818e;">A culminating public launch event is also planned.</span></div>
<div><span style="color: #45818e;"> </span></div>
<div><span style="color: #45818e;">There are no specific prerequisites for the class.</span></div>
<p><span style="color: #45818e;"> </span></p>
</div>
</div></div>


</div>
<div class="clear"></div>







  </div>
  <h3>Special Courses of Interest</h3>
  <div class="groupers">
    <div id="courses-dave-template" class="grid_12">
	<div class="course_title_div">
		<span class="bolded">
	History 139 C</span> Civil Rights and Social Movements in the U.S.	 </div>



<div class="body"><div class="course_logistics"><ul><li class="li-time">TTh 12:30-2</li><li class="li-instructor">W. Martin</li><li class="li-location">277 Cory</li><li class="li-units">4 Units</li><li class="li-cc">Class Number: 46370</li></ul></div><div class="cross-listed">Cross-listed with History C139C</div><div class="sections">Section 101 - Tu 5-6, 283 Dwinelle<br />
Section 102 - Wed 6-7, 179 Dwinelle<br />
Section 103 - Thurs 5-6, 183 Dwinelle<br />
Section 104 - Thurs 6-7, 183 Dwinelle</div><div class="expandable2"><p>Civil Rights and Social Movements in U.S. History presents a top-down (political and legal history), bottom-up (social and cultural history), and comparative (by race and ethnicity as well as region) view of America's struggles for racial equality from roughly World War II until the present. Beginning with the onset of World War II, America experienced not a singular, unitary Civil Rights Movement as is typically portrayed in standard textbook accounts and the collective memory but rather a variety of contemporaneous civil rights and their related social movements. These movements, moreover, did not follow a tidy chronological-geographic trajectory from South to North to West, nor were their participants merely black and white. Instead, from their inception, America's civil rights movements unfolded both beyond the South and beyond black and white. ";Civil Rights and Social Movements in U.S. History"; endeavors to equip students with a greater appreciation for the complexity of America's civil rights and social movements history, a complexity that neither a black / white nor nonwhite / white framework adequately captures. Put another way, ";Civil Rights and Social Movements in U.S. History"; will examine how the problem of the color line which W.E.B. DuBois deemed to be in 1903 the problem of the twentieth century might better be viewed as a problem of color lines. If America's demographics are increasingly beyond black and white, if ";the classic American dilemma has now become many dilemmas of race and ethnicity,"; as President Clinton put it in the late 1990s, if color lines now loom as the problem of the 21st century, then a course on America's civil rights and social movements past may very well offer a glimpse into America's civil rights and social movements present and future.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><em>. </em></p>
<p><em> </em></p>
<p><strong> </strong></p>
</div></div>


</div>
<div class="clear"></div>







  </div>
  <h3>Lower Division Courses of Interest</h3>
  <div class="groupers">
    <div id="courses-dave-template" class="grid_12">
	<div class="course_title_div">
		<span class="bolded">
	American Studies 24</span> Hamilton and the Federalist	 </div>



<div class="body"><div class="course_logistics"><ul><li class="li-time">M 10-11</li><li class="li-instructor">R. Hutson</li><li class="li-location">204 Dwinelle</li><li class="li-units">1 Units</li><li class="li-cc">Class Number: 46771</li></ul></div><div class="expandable2"><p>FRESHMAN SEMINAR. FRESHMEN ONLY!</p>
<p>The idea for the <em>Federalist </em>papers was Alexander Hamilton’s, and he wrote most of the papers, 51 of the 85. Hamilton invited James Madison (who became the fourth President of the U.S.) and John Jay to write the others.  Hamilton and Madison offer various arguments to try to convince citizens that the newly designed Constitution for a federal government should be accepted and ratified by the state of New York and beyond.   Do they convince you? As Jay notes in #2, this new constitution is to be “recommended” and debated.  Such a plan for a federal constitution for a free people who understand the need of a government has to be argued for, because there was already a government of the Continental Congress that seemed to some as working very well.  Discussion and debate belong intimately to such a republic, esp. a liberal republic. We cannot read and discuss all of the 85 papers, but we can look carefully at a few of them and engage in discussion and debate.  Obviously, the papers deal with serious and controversial issues. I want and expect discussion all of the time in every class.  Students will be evaluated on attendance and participation in the discussion.  There will be a short paper (5 pages) due at the end of the class.</p>
<p> </p>
</div></div>


</div>
<div class="clear"></div>







  </div>
</div></div>    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Current Courses &rarr; Honors Seminar</h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-courses-new view-id-courses_new view-display-id-page_2 view-dom-id-6a96af11e8a9246f3afa801f43fed78b">
            <div class="view-header">
      Displaying Courses 1 - 1 of 1 | <a href="/courses/fall">Reset Filters</a>    </div>
  
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
      <div class="view-grouping"><div class="view-grouping-header">Fall 2017</div><div class="view-grouping-content">  <h3>Honors Seminar</h3>
  <div class="groupers">
    <div id="courses-dave-template" class="grid_12">
	<div class="course_title_div">
		<span class="bolded">
	American Studies H 110</span> From SFMOMA to Ghost Ship: Exploring Bay Area Art Ecosystems	 </div>



<div class="body"><div class="course_logistics"><ul><li class="li-time">F 2-5</li><li class="li-instructor">J. Winet</li><li class="li-location">425 Doe</li><li class="li-units">4 Units</li><li class="li-cc">Class Number: 46190</li></ul></div><div class="expandable2"><div dir="ltr">
<p>THIS IS AN HONORS SEMINAR. PERMISSION OF FACULTY ADVISOR OR INSTRUCTOR IS REQUIRED TO ENROLL.</p>
<div><span style="color: #45818e;"> </span></div>
<div><span style="color: #45818e;" data-mce-mark="1">The Bay Area is home to a vibrant and diverse art scene, fueled by thousands of creative artists working in a wide range of media – and with an impressive array of interests. At the same time local and national pressures present formidable challenges to artists. This course will explore the range of environments artists inhabit and animate. </span></div>
<div><span style="color: #45818e;"> </span></div>
<div><span style="color: #45818e;">Working collaboratively, students will conduct public digital humanities research creating online multimedia mobile websites that highlight artist-centered organizations vital to the Area’s culture. Hands-on technical demonstrations and workshops will focus on audio, video and photography production using smart phones. Central to the class will be discussion of best practices for engagement – including the art and craft of interviews and approaches to documentary. </span></div>
<div><span style="color: #45818e;"> </span></div>
<div><span style="color: #45818e;">Seminar activities will include reading and writing assignments, media screenings, field trips to artists’ organizations, artist studios, museums and galleries, and in-class and on-site presentations by arts activists and civic leaders.</span></div>
<div><span style="color: #45818e;"> </span></div>
<div><span style="color: #45818e;">A culminating public launch event is also planned.</span></div>
<div><span style="color: #45818e;"> </span></div>
<div><span style="color: #45818e;">There are no specific prerequisites for the class.</span></div>
<p><span style="color: #45818e;"> </span></p>
</div>
</div></div>


</div>
<div class="clear"></div>







  </div>
</div></div>    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->
	<div class="clear"></div>

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Current Courses &rarr; Introductory Courses</h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-courses-new view-id-courses_new view-display-id-page_2 view-dom-id-6dc1cf221508293d5b34fccf5347b6d7">
            <div class="view-header">
      Displaying Courses 1 - 3 of 3 | <a href="/courses/fall">Reset Filters</a>    </div>
  
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
      <div class="view-grouping"><div class="view-grouping-header">Fall 2017</div><div class="view-grouping-content">  <h3>Introductory Courses</h3>
  <div class="groupers">
    <div id="courses-dave-template" class="grid_12">
	<div class="course_title_div">
		<span class="bolded">
	African American Studies 27 AC</span> Lives of Struggle: Minorities in Majority Culture	 </div>



<div class="body"><div class="course_logistics"><ul><li class="li-time">TTh 12:30-2</li><li class="li-instructor">M. Cohen</li><li class="li-location">145 Dwinelle</li><li class="li-units">3 Units</li><li class="li-cc">Class Number: 12321</li></ul></div><div class="sections">Sections -TO BE DETERMINED</div><div class="expandable2"><p>IN FALL 2017, THIS COURSE SATISFIES THE AMERICAN STUDIES 10 REQUIREMENT. The purpose of this course is to examine the many forms that the struggle of minorities can assume. The focus is on individual struggle and its outcome as reported and perceived by the individuals themselves. Members of three minority aggregates are considered: African Americans, Asian Americans (so called), and Chicano/Latino Americans. The choice of these three has to do with the different histories of members of these aggregrates. Such differences have produced somewhat different approaches to struggle.</p>
</div></div>


</div>
<div class="clear"></div>







  </div>
  <div class="groupers">
    <div id="courses-dave-template" class="grid_12">
	<div class="course_title_div">
		<span class="bolded">
	American Studies 10</span> Food Culture in America	 </div>



<div class="body"><div class="course_logistics"><ul><li class="li-time">TTh 11-12:30</li><li class="li-instructor">K. Moran, M. Lovell</li><li class="li-location">3 LeConte</li><li class="li-units">4 Units</li><li class="li-cc">Class Number: 22204</li></ul></div><div class="sections">Section 201                                         M 3-4, 115 Kroeber<br />
Section 202                                         M 12-1, 238 Kroeber<br />
Section 203                                         M 2-3, 238 Kroeber<br />
Section 204                                        M 1-2, 106 Wheeler</div><div class="expandable2"><p>This course will introduce students to the interdisciplinary field of American Studies, taking “Food” as its central theme. We will explore the social history, political economy and "aesthetics" of eating and cooking in America.  Specific topics will include the development and importance of New World agriculture, the design of shopping and eating spaces, eco history, the objects we use in the kitchen, the use of food as a metaphor in literature and in popular culture, food service workers, ethnic foods, food advertising, food photography, fast food, the “slow” food movement, and food biographies. We will also consider the specific food culture of Berkeley, and explore the rise of the so-called Berkeley "gourmet ghetto."</p>
<p> Course Goals:  This course is meant to enable you to think and do research as an interdisciplinary scholar, specifically to give you the tools to do readings of a literary text, a painting, a common object, a film, a space.  You will also learn the basics of conducting an interview, drawing a floorplan, recording and analyzing behaviors.  You will practice historical research—gathering and evaluating evidence--as well as practice the skills involved in finding a thesis and arguing it persuasively.  </p>
</div></div>


</div>
<div class="clear"></div>







  </div>
  <div class="groupers">
    <div id="courses-dave-template" class="grid_12">
	<div class="course_title_div">
		<span class="bolded">
	Letters and Science 40 C</span> Hollywood: The Place, the Fantasy, and the Industry	 </div>



<div class="body"><div class="course_logistics"><ul><li class="li-time">MW 12-2</li><li class="li-instructor">K. Moran</li><li class="li-location">141 McCone</li><li class="li-units">4 Units</li><li class="li-cc">Class Number: 44495</li></ul></div><div class="sections">Section 101 - M 9-10, 110 Barker<br />
Section 102 - Th 9-10, 115 Kroeber<br />
Section 103 - Th 2-3, 106 Dwinelle<br />
Section 104 - M 10-11, 115 Kroeber</div><div class="expandable2"><p><span>IN FALL 2017, THIS COURSE SATISFIES THE AMERICAN STUDIES 10 REQUIREMENT. This course is about the history of the Hollywood "Dream Factory," focusing on both parts of that phrase. We will examine the historical and geographical development of the motion picture industry from the rise of the studio system to the "new" entertainment economy of the 1980's, as we think about the way films have constructed powerful and productive fantasies about the boundaries between public and private, work and play, commerce and art, fantasy and reality.  Our topics will include the history of labor in the culture industry, the implications of shifts in the spatial organization of film production, and the effects of Hollywood on the larger politics of southern California.  We will also discuss the way Hollywood has framed its own history by viewing a number of "movies about movies," including Sullivan's Travels, Singin' in the Rain, Sunset Boulevard, and The Player</span></p>
</div></div>


</div>
<div class="clear"></div>







  </div>
</div></div>    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->
	<div class="clear"></div>

	<!--<div id="breadcrumb-wrap" class="grid_12"><p id="breadcrumbs">You are here: &nbsp; <a href="/">Home</a> &nbsp; &#62;  &nbsp; <a href="/courses/spring" title="">Courses</a> &nbsp; &#62;  &nbsp; <a href="/courses/fall">Lower Division Courses Of Interest</a></p></div>-->

	<!-- Tabs and Messages -->

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Current Courses &rarr; Lower Division Courses Of Interest</h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-courses-new view-id-courses_new view-display-id-page_2 view-dom-id-8044284ee812db7c62e7eb3b8f33965f">
            <div class="view-header">
      Displaying Courses 1 - 1 of 1 | <a href="/courses/fall">Reset Filters</a>    </div>
  
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
      <div class="view-grouping"><div class="view-grouping-header">Fall 2017</div><div class="view-grouping-content">  <h3>Lower Division Courses of Interest</h3>
  <div class="groupers">
    <div id="courses-dave-template" class="grid_12">
	<div class="course_title_div">
		<span class="bolded">
	American Studies 24</span> Hamilton and the Federalist	 </div>



<div class="body"><div class="course_logistics"><ul><li class="li-time">M 10-11</li><li class="li-instructor">R. Hutson</li><li class="li-location">204 Dwinelle</li><li class="li-units">1 Units</li><li class="li-cc">Class Number: 46771</li></ul></div><div class="expandable2"><p>FRESHMAN SEMINAR. FRESHMEN ONLY!</p>
<p>The idea for the <em>Federalist </em>papers was Alexander Hamilton’s, and he wrote most of the papers, 51 of the 85. Hamilton invited James Madison (who became the fourth President of the U.S.) and John Jay to write the others.  Hamilton and Madison offer various arguments to try to convince citizens that the newly designed Constitution for a federal government should be accepted and ratified by the state of New York and beyond.   Do they convince you? As Jay notes in #2, this new constitution is to be “recommended” and debated.  Such a plan for a federal constitution for a free people who understand the need of a government has to be argued for, because there was already a government of the Continental Congress that seemed to some as working very well.  Discussion and debate belong intimately to such a republic, esp. a liberal republic. We cannot read and discuss all of the 85 papers, but we can look carefully at a few of them and engage in discussion and debate.  Obviously, the papers deal with serious and controversial issues. I want and expect discussion all of the time in every class.  Students will be evaluated on attendance and participation in the discussion.  There will be a short paper (5 pages) due at the end of the class.</p>
<p> </p>
</div></div>


</div>
<div class="clear"></div>







  </div>
</div></div>    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>

			<div class="container_12 clearfix" id="mb3" role="">
			  <div class="region region-mb">
