			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Current Courses &rarr; Time Courses</h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-courses-new view-id-courses_new view-display-id-page_3 view-dom-id-ddadcda10e8fb03e9e6ca2dc64a2257d">
            <div class="view-header">
      Displaying Courses 1 - 4 of 4 | <a href="/courses/spring">Reset Filters</a>    </div>
  
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
      <div class="view-grouping"><div class="view-grouping-header">Spring 2018</div><div class="view-grouping-content">  <h3>Time Courses</h3>
  <div class="groupers">
    <div id="courses-dave-template" class="grid_12">
	<div class="course_title_div">
		<span class="bolded">
	American Studies 101</span> The Great Exhaling: Culture, Politics, and History 1946-1952	 </div>



<div class="body"><div class="course_logistics"><ul><li class="li-time">MW 4-6</li><li class="li-instructor">G. Marcus &amp; K. Moran</li><li class="li-location">240 Mulford</li><li class="li-units">4 Units</li><li class="li-cc">Class Number: 39408</li></ul></div><div class="sections">Sec. 101: 			M 9-10, 126 Wheeler<br />
Sec. 102:				W 10-11, 238 Kroeber<br />
</div><div class="expandable2"><p>1948 was the year that America—after the Great depression, after the Second World War, after sixteen years of the all but revolutionary experiment in national government of the New Deal—let out its collective breath. Finally, that great exhaling said, we can go back to real life but what was “real life?” Centering on 1948, but moving a few years back and a few years forward, this class will explore the sometimes instantly celebrated, sometimes all but subterranean experiments in American culture and literature that tried to raise and answer that question. The artists, writers, filmmakers, painters, musicians, poets, and social theorists who emerged to tell that national story included Miles Davis and Jack Kerouac, Allen Ginsberg and Ross McDonald, J.D. Salinger and Ray Bradbury, David Riesman and Marshall McLuhan. This course will follow the traces of this explosion as well as contextualize the American that was being born. It will include films, popular music, Life Magazine, advertising culture and television as well as novels, poetry and discussions of visual images.</p>
</div></div>


</div>
<div class="clear"></div>







  </div>
  <div class="groupers">
    <div id="courses-dave-template" class="grid_12">
	<div class="course_title_div">
		<span class="bolded">
	American Studies 101</span> Race, Class, and Nutrition in the Progressive Era 	 </div>



<div class="body"><div class="course_logistics"><ul><li class="li-time">MW 12-2</li><li class="li-instructor">J. Walker</li><li class="li-location">240 Mulford</li><li class="li-units">4 Units</li><li class="li-cc">Class Number: 39408</li></ul></div><div class="expandable2"><p><br class="Apple-interchange-newline" />The Progressive era saw waves of new immigrant communities to urban centers, dramatic shifts in industrial manufacturing technology, and war. As such what it meant to be an American also shifted toward an emphasis on strenuous outdoor work, collective investment in morality, and new standards around food and nutrition. This course considers how the culture, politics and policies of this time reinforced a racialized standard for the ideal American body. We will investigate the historical contexts that give rise to the proper diet, the role of the USDA, and our modern concepts of nutrition. Importantly, we will also consider how these arise in conversation with the institutionalization of scientific racism, representations of the changing ethnic food landscape in America’s nascent urban centers, and the construction of the unhealthy and immoral “other.” We will draw from primary sources like dietary reports, USDA pamphlets, packaged food labels, and health and lifestyle manuals to understand the material world of Americans negotiating their food, classed, and raced lives.</p>
<p> </p>
</div></div>


</div>
<div class="clear"></div>







  </div>
  <div class="groupers">
    <div id="courses-dave-template" class="grid_12">
	<div class="course_title_div">
		<span class="bolded">
	American Studies 102</span> Indigenous California History, Literature, and Art	 </div>



<div class="body"><div class="course_logistics"><ul><li class="li-time">MWF 12-1</li><li class="li-instructor">H. Wong</li><li class="li-location">103 Moffitt</li><li class="li-units">4 Units</li><li class="li-cc">Class Number: 39445</li></ul></div><div class="expandable2"><p><em>This course can be used for TIME, PLACE, or PRE-1900 major requirements, depending on the research you do for the course.</em></p>
<div> </div>
<p>In this course, we will examine the indigenous history, literature, and art of California, with an emphasis on northern California. We will read primary works by Native California writers, look at the artwork of Native California artists, and learn about the history and cultures of indigenous people in California. In addition, we will schedule visits to the archives of the Phoebe A. Hearst Museum of Anthropology and the Bancroft Library here on campus as well as historic sites and cultural institutions locally. We may also go on a field trip or two.</p>
</div></div>


</div>
<div class="clear"></div>







  </div>
  <div class="groupers">
    <div id="courses-dave-template" class="grid_12">
	<div class="course_title_div">
		<span class="bolded">
	History 122 AC</span> Antebellum America: The Advent of Mass Society 	 </div>



<div class="body"><div class="course_logistics"><ul><li class="li-time">MWF 1-2</li><li class="li-instructor">S. McBride</li><li class="li-location">2060 VLSB</li><li class="li-units">4 Units</li><li class="li-cc">Class Number: 32285</li></ul></div><div class="expandable2"><p>This course examines half a century of life in the United States (roughly from the War of 1812 until the secession of the Southern states), focusing on race relations, westward expansion, class formation, immigration, religion, sexuality, popular culture, and everyday life. Assigned readings will consist largely of first-person narratives in which women and men of a range of ethnic and cultural backgrounds construct distinctive visions of life in the new nation. </p>
</div></div>


</div>
<div class="clear"></div>







  </div>
</div></div>    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->
	<div class="clear"></div>

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Summer Courses</h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-views-courses-new-block-3" class="block block-views"><div class="widget bottom">    <div class="view-content">
        <span class="views-summary views-summary-unformatted">        <a href="/courses/summer/time-courses">Time Courses</a>
          (1)
      </span>    </div>
  </div><div class="clear"></div></div><div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-courses-new view-id-courses_new view-display-id-page_4 view-dom-id-9d56b8c086300107322b8ab241a4733d">
            <div class="view-header">
      Displaying Courses 1 - 1 of 1 | <a href="/courses/summer">Reset Filters</a>    </div>
  
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
      <div class="view-grouping"><div class="view-grouping-header">Summer 2018</div><div class="view-grouping-content">  <h3>Time Courses</h3>
  <div class="groupers">
    <div id="courses-dave-template" class="grid_12">
	<div class="course_title_div">
		<span class="bolded">
	American Studies 101 AC</span> The Age of Monopoly	 </div>



<div class="body"><div class="course_logistics"><ul><li class="li-time">MTW 12-3</li><li class="li-instructor">M. Cohen</li><li class="li-location">155 Kroeber</li><li class="li-units">4 Units</li><li class="li-cc">Class Number: 14116</li></ul></div><div class="expandable2"><div><strong><strong><span style="color: #0b5394;"><span>Summer 2018 Session A</span><span> </span><span><br /></span></span></strong></strong></div>
<div> 
<div>
<p>First Great Depression, the United States of America transformed itself from an isolationist and agricultural country into the richest, most powerful nation in the world. This era is characterized by the stunning growth of industrial and finance capitalism and the seemingly insignificant birth of what quickly became the dominant institution in our world: the modern business corporation. The building of vast corporate monopolies in money, steel, tobacco, movies, food, oil, electricity, organized crime, etc. reorganized every aspect of American life and culture from our cities to our sports, from our politics to our popular entertainment. The Age of Monopoly represents the birth of modern America, and with these great changes came epic social, sexual and racial conflicts characterized by the often violent clash of labor and capital, the repression of African American rights and the triumph of white supremacy, the cataclysmic end to 400 years of Indian wars, the challenge of feminism and the New Woman, the confrontation of Americans with the rest of the world in the form of mass immigration and imperial expansion, the rise of major reform and revolutionary movements, and the growth of state institutions dedicated to stopping them. The focus of this class will be to consider the economic and political changes of the Age of Monopoly through a study of its culture, for it was this half-century that gave birth to modern American culture in the form of illustrated magazines and comic strips, world's fairs and amusement parks, Wild West shows and vaudeville, the advertising and public relations industry, window shopping and department stores, skyscrapers and national parks, military buildups and IQ tests, talk radio and Jazz music, automobiles and suburbs, and most importantly, the Hollywood movie.</p>
</div>
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<p><strong>NOTE: THIS COURSE SATISFIEST THE UNIVERSITY'S AMERICAN CULTURES REQUIREMENT. </strong></p>
<p><strong> </strong></p></div>
</div></div>


</div>
<div class="clear"></div>







  </div>
</div></div>    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->
	<div class="clear"></div>

	<!-- Breadcrumb -->
	<!--<div id="breadcrumb-wrap" class="grid_12"><p id="breadcrumbs">You are here: &nbsp; <a href="/">Home</a> &nbsp; &#62;  &nbsp; <a href="/courses/spring" title="">Courses</a> &nbsp; &#62;  &nbsp; <a href="/courses/summer">Introductory Courses</a></p></div>-->

	<!-- Tabs and Messages -->
	    <div class="clear"></div><div class="clear"></div>    <div class="clear"></div><div class="clear"></div>

	
			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12">

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Current Courses &rarr; Time Courses</h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-courses-new view-id-courses_new view-display-id-page_4 view-dom-id-cdc3d0bc38143bcf5aa583e6b01eb6c9">
            <div class="view-header">
      Displaying Courses 1 - 1 of 1 | <a href="/courses/summer">Reset Filters</a>    </div>
  
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
      <div class="view-grouping"><div class="view-grouping-header">Summer 2018</div><div class="view-grouping-content">  <h3>Time Courses</h3>
  <div class="groupers">
    <div id="courses-dave-template" class="grid_12">
	<div class="course_title_div">
		<span class="bolded">
	American Studies 101 AC</span> The Age of Monopoly	 </div>



<div class="body"><div class="course_logistics"><ul><li class="li-time">MTW 12-3</li><li class="li-instructor">M. Cohen</li><li class="li-location">155 Kroeber</li><li class="li-units">4 Units</li><li class="li-cc">Class Number: 14116</li></ul></div><div class="expandable2"><div><strong><strong><span style="color: #0b5394;"><span>Summer 2018 Session A</span><span> </span><span><br /></span></span></strong></strong></div>
<div> 
<div>
<p>First Great Depression, the United States of America transformed itself from an isolationist and agricultural country into the richest, most powerful nation in the world. This era is characterized by the stunning growth of industrial and finance capitalism and the seemingly insignificant birth of what quickly became the dominant institution in our world: the modern business corporation. The building of vast corporate monopolies in money, steel, tobacco, movies, food, oil, electricity, organized crime, etc. reorganized every aspect of American life and culture from our cities to our sports, from our politics to our popular entertainment. The Age of Monopoly represents the birth of modern America, and with these great changes came epic social, sexual and racial conflicts characterized by the often violent clash of labor and capital, the repression of African American rights and the triumph of white supremacy, the cataclysmic end to 400 years of Indian wars, the challenge of feminism and the New Woman, the confrontation of Americans with the rest of the world in the form of mass immigration and imperial expansion, the rise of major reform and revolutionary movements, and the growth of state institutions dedicated to stopping them. The focus of this class will be to consider the economic and political changes of the Age of Monopoly through a study of its culture, for it was this half-century that gave birth to modern American culture in the form of illustrated magazines and comic strips, world's fairs and amusement parks, Wild West shows and vaudeville, the advertising and public relations industry, window shopping and department stores, skyscrapers and national parks, military buildups and IQ tests, talk radio and Jazz music, automobiles and suburbs, and most importantly, the Hollywood movie.</p>
</div>
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<p><strong>NOTE: THIS COURSE SATISFIEST THE UNIVERSITY'S AMERICAN CULTURES REQUIREMENT. </strong></p>
<p><strong> </strong></p></div>
</div></div>


</div>
<div class="clear"></div>







  </div>
</div></div>    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->
	<div class="clear"></div>

	<!-- Breadcrumb -->
	<!--<div id="breadcrumb-wrap" class="grid_12"><p id="breadcrumbs">You are here: &nbsp; <a href="/">Home</a> &nbsp; &#62;  &nbsp; <a href="/about-major" title="">Major</a></p></div>-->

	<!-- Tabs and Messages -->
	    <div class="clear"></div><div class="clear"></div>    <div class="clear"></div><div class="clear"></div>

	
			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Profile of Graduates</h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page view-dom-id-2f443c7ed868772cd1e3a289fe38a2b6">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <h3>Class of <span class="date-display-single">2017</span></h3>
  <div class="views-row views-row-1 clearfix">
      
          <h3 class="title"><strong>Rosemarie Alejandrino :</strong> - <a href="graduates/detail/3698">Popular Culture and the American Mediascape</a></h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/rosemarie%20alejandrino%20crop.png" title="Rosemarie Alejandrino " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3698-G41k27wf1rg" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/rosemarie%20alejandrino%20crop.png?itok=kqWHiKOe" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>After graduating with honors and a double major in English, Rosemarie went on to pursue a Master's degree in Specialized Journalism (The Arts) at the University of Southern California. She is a first-generation college student and, in turn, is the first in her family to pursue a post-graduate degree. She is also the Rotten Tomatoes Fellow in Digital Innovation and Film Criticism, working with the company to redefine the role of the critic in the modern era. Along with Charisse Celestial ('17), she is the co-founder of FLASH THRIVE zine collective, publishing art zines with work by local creatives.</p>
 <div class="read-more-grad"><a href="graduates/detail/3698">Read more about Rosemarie's Thesis and Area of Concentration</a></div>    </div>
  <div class="views-row views-row-2 clearfix">
      
          <h3 class="title"><strong>Hunter Cobleigh :</strong> - <a href="graduates/detail/3701">Consumerism and American Popular Culture</a></h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/hunter%20cobleigh.png" title="Hunter Cobleigh " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3701-G41k27wf1rg" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/hunter%20cobleigh.png?itok=Qg4ijvm2" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>One month after graduation, Hunter packed up and moved to Melbourne, Australia, on a yearlong work and holiday visa.  In addition to exploring the country, he is currently working in advertising for the Australian Traffic Network, where he is putting his area of concentration to work. Before returning to the U.S. either to continue a career in media or to pursue a graduate degree, Hunter plans to visit more of the South Pacific.</p>
 <div class="read-more-grad"><a href="graduates/detail/3701">Read more about Hunter's Thesis and Area of Concentration</a></div>    </div>
  <div class="views-row views-row-3 clearfix">
      
          <h3 class="title"><strong>Miesha Garnett :</strong> - <a href="graduates/detail/3695">Race, Family, and Childhood</a></h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/miesha%20garnett%20crop.png" title="Miesha Garnett " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3695-G41k27wf1rg" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/miesha%20garnett%20crop.png?itok=exnqEYVu" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>Miesha currently works for the Solano County Office of Education in the Special Education department. She is studying for both the CBEST and the Housing and Urban Development written exam. With the goal of a career that allows her to make a positive impact on the community in which she lives, Miesha also plans to pursue a Master's in Public Health Community Education.</p>
 <div class="read-more-grad"><a href="graduates/detail/3695">Read more about Miesha's Thesis and Area of Concentration</a></div>    </div>
  <div class="views-row views-row-4 clearfix">
      
          <h3 class="title"><strong>Robert Gibbons :</strong> - <a href="graduates/detail/3697">Culture, Economy, and the American City</a></h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/robert%20gibbons.jpg" title="Robert Gibbons " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3697-G41k27wf1rg" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/robert%20gibbons.jpg?itok=KSl-c8qo" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>After graduation, Robert accepted a full-time position with Outward Bound USA, where he collaborated with ten of the most experienced Outward Bound educators to form a National Learning Lab tasked with re-evaluating Outward Bound's curriculum with the aim of adapting it to suit K-5th graders in a traditional educational setting. Robert led a trial run of such a program this summer at an elementary school in Omaha with great success and will be rolling out five programs to the Omaha Public School system in 2017-2018.  Robert is eager to pursue a Master’s in Public Policy.</p>
 <div class="read-more-grad"><a href="graduates/detail/3697">Read more about Robert's Thesis and Area of Concentration</a></div>    </div>
  <div class="views-row views-row-5 clearfix">
      
          <h3 class="title"><strong>Sally Littlefield :</strong> - <a href="graduates/detail/3700">Twentieth Century American Culture</a></h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/sally%20littlefield.jpg" title="Sally Littlefield " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3700-G41k27wf1rg" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/sally%20littlefield.jpg?itok=4bEWSozz" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>Sally Littlefield currently works for the Public Education Campaigns and Programs team at Futures Without Violence, a San Francisco-based national nonprofit organization dedicated to ending violence against women and children. Sally thanks her American Studies background for giving her the ability to understand the very real role culture plays in shaping our society. This knowledge has proven invaluable in her work developing public awareness campaigns that aim to break cultural norms that disempower women.</p>
 <div class="read-more-grad"><a href="graduates/detail/3700">Read more about Sally's Thesis and Area of Concentration</a></div>    </div>
    </div>

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Ivan Boekelheide </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-dd4863933a0bfcc698e55ee27e6e1bfe">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    &quot;&#039;Deadwood&#039;: A Western Reborn or the Rebirth of the Western?&quot;  </h3>  
          <p><span>The Western has long held an important place in American cinema, and its role has evolved with the changing culture of American society. Through a structural analysis of the HBO series, Deadwood, Ivan Boekelheide's thesis argues that the Western no longer foregrounds the search for heroic morality, preferring to delight in social and moral ambiguities.</span></p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    American Visual Culture  </h3>  
          <p>American Studies 110: Advertising America<br />Film 108: Silent Films<br />Film 108<strong>:</strong> Animation<br />History of Art 185A: American Art from 1800<br />American Studies H110: American National Character (Honors Seminar)<br />Political Science 109F: Special Topics in American Politics</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Ivan Boekelheide</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/ivan.jpg" title="Ivan Boekelheide " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3395-scEzMZ-Bz6U" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/ivan.jpg?itok=HEEeiOY5" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p><span>Upon graduating in May 2007, Ivan went to Thailand and Myanmar where he spent nearly two years as a teacher. On returning to the U.S., Ivan completed a Master's degree in Law and Diplomacy at the Fletcher School at Tufts University.  Currently, Ivan works to strengthen economic relations between the U.S. and Southeast Asia at the U.S. Chamber of Commerce in Washington, D.C.<br /></span></p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Cleavon Gilman </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-7ff251f0fcde852dbd7473404cfba16f">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    &quot;William Nelson Colson: The Effects of Northernization and Francization on Southern Negroes in the Pursuit of Unequivocal Equality (1915-1922)&quot;  </h3>  
          <div class="thesis-image"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/clevon.thesis.jpg" title="Cleavon Gilman " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3396-vAMNNujnlG0" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/medium/public/clevon.thesis.jpg?itok=RtuBry9P" width="167" height="220" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p><span>Through the life and social experience of United States Army Second Lieutenant William Nelson Colson Cleavon Gilman's honors thesis examines the manner in which the Northernization and subsequent Francization of Southern Negro soldiers during the 1910s and 20s produced an unprecedented amount of conscientious objectors. A comparison between the post-Reconstruction and Civil War generations shows that the latter was more passive towards whites because they lived under slave rule. On the other hand, the Northernization of the post-Reconstruction generation produced conscientious objectors dissatisfied with southern living conditions; consequently, many Northernized Negroes chose to remain in the North where racism was much more negligible. Furthermore, the Francization of the Northernized Negro solider during World War I produced the unprecedented militant New Negro solider who militantly demanded equality when provoked or witnessed injustices towards other Negroes.</span></p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    Diversity and Mobility in the U.S.  </h3>  
          <p>Sociology 140: Political Sociology<br />African American Studies159: Hip Hop<br />Peace and Conflict Studies 125AC:<strong> </strong>War, Culture, &amp; Society<br />Chicano Studies 180: Topics in Chicano Studies<br />Ethnic Studies 103A: Racialization and Empire<br />Education 190: Current Issues in Education</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Cleavon Gilman</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/clevon.jpg" title="Cleavon Gilman " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3396-vAMNNujnlG0" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/clevon.jpg?itok=nqQvxJb9" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p><span>After graduating in 2009, Cleavon completed a post-Baccalaureate in Physiology at California State University East Bay.  In 2016 he became of Doctor of Medicine after completing training at UCSF<span>.</span><br /></span></p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Everardo Mora </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-312b71d47bb07767f264a364dc5685ad">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    &quot;Life behind the &#039;Shield:&#039; Cannery Culture and the &#039;Farandula&#039; at Del Monte Plant 3&quot;  </h3>  
          <div class="thesis-image"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/everardo.thesis.jpg" title="Everardo Mora " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3397-G4RJAwn2dQU" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/medium/public/everardo.thesis.jpg?itok=1yrZJ9Ki" width="168" height="220" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p><span>For more than a century, Del Monte's red tomato "Shield" has represented the "Quality" of its products. Everardo Mora explains that Del Monte's red tomato "Shield" also represents the "Quality" of its workforce. Based on the oral histories of Latino cannery workers, Mora documents and explores the meaning of "cannery culture" and the important contributions this "cannery community" made to California's rich agricultural history.</span></p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    City Planning, Public Policy, and Minority Communities  </h3>  
          <p>American Studies H110:<strong> </strong><span>Methods, Histories, and Controversies (Honors Seminar)</span><br />American Studies C134:<span> Information Technology &amp; Society</span><br />American Studies 110:<span> Sociology of Sister-Cities</span><br />Ethnic Studies 130AC:<span> Multicultural America</span><br />Chicano Studies 150B:<span> History of the Southwest</span><br />Native American Studies 102:<span> Critical Native American Legal and Policy Studies</span></p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Everardo Mora</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/everardo.jpg" title="Everardo Mora " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3397-G4RJAwn2dQU" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/everardo.jpg?itok=bTD2Ia7r" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p><span>As one of four recipients of the 2009 Judith Lee Stronach Baccalaureate Prize, Everardo Mora received $20,000 and a Visiting Scholar placement at UC Berkeley in order to continue his research on "cannery culture." His goal was to produce a narrative infused with the voices, stories, and experiences of Latino cannery workers in order to better understand ethnic diversity, the culture of mass production, language and literacy, and identity construction on the shop floor of the last full-scale cannery to close in the Silicon Valley, a valley that once was known as the Valley of Heart's Delight. Everardo currently works as a Project Manager at Orton Development, Inc.<br /></span></p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Yi-Ning Chiu </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-06e1003b0c08ceec326e22de0b2e0381">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    &quot;Glory and Honor of the Nations: The Promise of Multicultural Theological Formations in Evangelical America&quot;  </h3>  
          <p>Yi-Ning Chiu's thesis outlines the experiences of evangelical Christians of color living in the United States between 1950 and the present, and situates their experiences within the broader narrative of evangelical Christianity in America.  Using interviews with ethnic evangelical students at UC Berkeley, writings on spirituality produced by ethnic evangelical communities, and a study of historically significant interactions between ethnic and white evangelicals in America, it paints a portrait of evangelical Americans of the past half-century.  With this portrait, it challenges the pervasive notion that evangelicalism equals whiteness and conservatism, and then traces the ways in which ethnic believers have occupied and shaped America's religious landscape alongside their white counterparts.</p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    Race, Nation, and International Relations, 1945-Present  </h3>  
          <p>International and Area Studies 115: Global Poverty<br />History 137AC: Repeopling America<br />History 132B: Intellectual History of the United States since 1865<br />American Studies H110: American National Character<br />Political Science 144B: Korean Politics<br />Sociology 131AC: Race and Ethnic Relations: U.S. American Cultures</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Yi-Ning Chiu</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Yi-Ning%20Chiu.jpg" title="Yi-Ning Chiu " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3398-e9OnJNApksY" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/Yi-Ning%20Chiu.jpg?itok=251yzLzd" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>After graduating in 2012, Yi-Ning worked briefly for an online education startup before returning to the American Studies department, where she was a section leader for American Studies 10: "Hollywood: The Place, the Industry, the Fantasy."  After continuing to work as a Reader for American Studies courses and co-pastoring the college fellowship of Ark Ministries of Berkeley, a local non-denominational, multi-ethnic church, Yi-Ning joined the team at Year Up, an award-winning national 501(c)3 organization striving to close the Opportunity Divide by equipping urban young adults ages 18-24 to reach their potential through professional careers and higher education.  She works there as an Internship Services Specialist.</p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Patricia Boone </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-6879a6bcaa79f9045f79a81bfbbe77b5">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    Modern Day Prostitution and the Systematic Subjugation of the Black Female Body and Spirit  </h3>  
          <p>American society is sympathetic to sex-trafficked women and children from Asian and European countries; however, Black female prostitutes from urban locations such as East Oakland are often forgotten.  By actively engaging in cognitive dissonance around race, gender, and class, Americans fail to recognize the humanity of Black women and girls involved in street prostitution.  Feelings of indifference toward Black female prostitutes convey that the Black female body, even today, is valued less than any other body.  Inadvertently, this same dissonance benefits exploiters and consumers of the sex trade, rendering Black women and girls in prostitution disposable, culpable, and invisible.  However, depressingly so, this construction of the Black female body as immoral and more blameworthy is hardly new, rather it harkens back to old practices of chattel slavery and Victorian-era politics.  Patricia Boone's honors thesis argues that in order for Americans to see the humanity in Black female prostitutes, the idea that the Black body is incapable of victimization must be discarded, so that Black women and girls are given the same priority, concern, and protection as any other victim of commercial sexual exploitation.</p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    Race, Law, and Juvenile Delinquency  </h3>  
          <p>Sociology 110: Organizations and Social Institutions<br />History 100: Crime, Punishment, and Power<br />Legal Studies 163: Juvenile Justice<br />Sociology 124: Sociology of Poverty<br />Legal Studies 102: Policing and Society<br />Social Welfare 107: Foundations, Philanthropy, and the Social Services</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Patricia Boone</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Patricia%20Boone.jpg" title="Patricia Boone " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3399-M-su2IFOVz0" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/Patricia%20Boone.jpg?itok=Ps1wkFrp" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>Shortly after graduation in May 2013, Patricia packed her car and drove solo heading East with an eagerness to take what she learned at UC Berkeley and explore an expanding world.  Her road trip took a total of ten days, during which Patricia camped under the stars in Utah, danced in cowboy saloons in Wyoming, and witnessed electric skies over Nebraska.  In 2016 Patricia graduated from Northwestern School of Law, and and co-founded CompassBlu, LLC, a synergistic and diverse consulting firm that connects people to their purpose, producing results that inspire global change.</p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Theresa Berger </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-36dd13245555d3a38d982323aa47efb8">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    &quot;I Love Ethel: Friendship and I Love Lucy in the Postwar Period and Today&quot;  </h3>  
          <div class="thesis-image"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Berger-%20I%20LOve%20Ethel.png" title="Theresa Berger " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3408-GoKnUW13Pa0" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/medium/public/Berger-%20I%20LOve%20Ethel.png?itok=lgYzaPTo" width="170" height="220" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>Often cited as one of, if not the greatest television show of all time, <em>I Love Lucy</em> has captured the attention of critics, audiences, and fans alike for decades.  While much has been written of the show and the antics of zany "fifties" housewife Lucy Ricardo's failed attempts to make it in show business, almost nothing exists about Lucy's sidekick and affable partner-in-crime, Ethel Mertz.  Theresa Berger's honors thesis focuses on filling in this incredible gap in the canon of Lucy studies by exploring the theme and character of female friendship in the show.  By combining magazine and newspaper articles, cast and crew interviews, and individual episode analyses with cultural history, feminist theory, and current sociological understandings of female friendship, the lens of "friendship studies" develops as a way to understand what <em>I Love Lucy</em> represented to female audiences both in the 1950s as well as today.  From the simultaneous challenge and reassertion of gender norms to the growing emphases on upward mobility and consumer spending that define our cultural understanding of the decade (and still mean something in the present), Theresa argues that the friends in <em>I Love Lucy</em> reflect an oscillating and thus more historically accurate representation of the place and stance of white, suburban women in the fifties than  the show's red-headed female lead could ever embody.  In the process, it becomes clear that it was not just Lucy, but a number of talented and interconnected women in the show that all "[had] some 'splainin' to do."</p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    Twentieth Century American Cultural History  </h3>  
          <p>American Studies 101: The Atomic Age<br />American Studies 101AC: World War II<br />American Studies 101: The Birth of Consumer Society in the U.S.<br />American Studies 101: The Great Exhaling: Politics, Culture, and History 1956-1952<br />American Studies 180A: Advertising America<br />American Studies H110: The New Literary History of America</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Theresa Berger</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Theresa%20Berger.jpg" title="Theresa Berger " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3408-GoKnUW13Pa0" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/Theresa%20Berger.jpg?itok=KPgp5EhS" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>Since October 2013, Theresa has been working as a substitute teacher for a high school Advanced Placement English Literature class, where she loves using her American Studies background to draw on history, movies, and culture as ways to engage students and show them that what they are reading is more than just a series of words on a page.  She has also been a section leader and course assistant for a number of American Studies courses, including: AS 188D: San Francisco Detectives and AS 188K: American Horrors: Monsters in US Cinema and Literature (Summer 2013); AS 111/ English C136: The Great Exhaling (Spring 2014); AS 101: World War II (Fall 2014); and AS 101: World War II and AS C111/ English C136: The Gilded Age (Fall 2015).  In August 2016 Theresa will begin the Master's in History program at San Francisco State University, and on completion will apply to Ph.D. programs.</p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Robert Cancio </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-16210221281a42ab32fb0ad7fc93e013">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    &quot;Migration Los Angeles: The Story of a Cultural Landscape&quot;  </h3>  
          <div class="thesis-image"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Cancio-Migration.png" title="Robert Cancio " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3409-GYV0YJfO0fQ" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/medium/public/Cancio-Migration.png?itok=glyFBEA4" width="170" height="220" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>Robert Cancio's thesis centers on migration as a cultural work, and examines a case study of 20th century Los Angeles through which he argued that cultural identities of migrants in 20th century Los Angeles create specific impressions or cultural landscapes.  Through the use of quantitative methods, Robert demonstrated that not only is Los Angeles a pluralist society rather than a melting pot, but also that there is one similarity within all migrational groups, specifically those that migrate(d) to Los Angeles, which is possessing and practicing a culture of upward mobility through public education.</p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    Economic Effects of Immigration  </h3>  
          <p>Legal Studies 132AC: Immigration and Citizenship<br />Demography 145AC: American Immigrant Experience<br />Chicano Studies 159: Mexican Immigration<br />Chicano Studies 163: Caribbean Migration<br />Ethnic Studies 103A: Racialization and Empire<br />Sociology 190AC: Seminar on Immigration in the United States</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Robert Cancio</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Robert%20Cancio.jpg" title="Robert Cancio " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3409-GYV0YJfO0fQ" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/Robert%20Cancio.jpg?itok=jJxbLz_Z" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>After a May 2013 graduation, Robert moved back to Los Angeles to spend time with his family before embarking on a cross-country trip cutting through the southern United States.  He backpacked in Tuolumne Meadows in Yosemite; hiked through the Grand Canyon in Arizona; visited Fort Selden State Monument, a former United States Army post for the Buffalo soldiers in New Mexico; toured the Alamo in Texas; feasted on Cajun shrimp in New Orleans; and visited Disney World in Florida--a trip her is certain American Studies students would appreciate.  Robert is currently pursuing a Ph.D. in Sociology at the University of Miami, where he hopes to build on his interdisciplinary training in American Studies.</p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Jen Kim </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-af1c212a7548804445acedd54b0b39a9">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    &quot;The Right to Oakland: The Power, Politics, and Planning Behind Jerry Brown’s 10k Plan&quot;  </h3>  
          <p>Jen Kim's honors thesis analyzes the housing and development policies under Jerry Brown's mayoral administration during the late 1990s in order to better understand the current development patterns that are radically transforming the city of Oakland.  Jen argues that Brown's 10k housing initiative and the community's response to the program mark an important "affordable housing moment" that has influenced the trajectory of neoliberal local development and oppositional organizing strategies.  Using a Right to the City framework, Jen explores the themes of power, politics, and planning that shape urban development not only in Oakland but also in every major city across the U.S. </p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    Public Policy and the Urban Community  </h3>  
          <p>City &amp; Regional Planning 118AC: The Urban Community<br />Public Policy C103: Wealth and Poverty<br />American Studies H110: American National Character<br />Sociology 130: Social Inequalities: American Cultures<br />History 136AC: Gender Matters in Twentieth Century America<br />African American Studies 119: Drugs and Race in U.S. History</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Jen Kim</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Jen%20Kim.jpg" title="Jen Kim " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3410-NKewnOJoFsY" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/Jen%20Kim.jpg?itok=SoQEI69z" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>During the summer following a May 2013 graduation, Jen worked as a public housing organizer for a community-based organization in the Lower East Side of New York City.  She is currently working toward a Master's in Urban and Regional Planning at UCLA, with a focus on community economic development and housing.  She is most interested in learning about alternative development models and plans to continue organizing for more equitable communities.</p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->
	<div class="clear"></div>

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Robyn Taylor </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-6b2510b9c39f3542758b5749a07ea9f1">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    &quot;Whitman and Linyekula Share Multitudes: Dancing the Space of Names&quot;  </h3>  
          <div class="thesis-image"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Taylor-Whitman%20and%20Linyekula.png" title="Robyn Taylor " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3411-O4gV201IoZA" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/medium/public/Taylor-Whitman%20and%20Linyekula.png?itok=FlP_ma2F" width="170" height="220" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>Congolese dancer and choreographer Faustin Linyekula remarked during an interview with playwright Peter Sellars that, "dance helps [him] to remember [his] name."  Robyn Taylor's creative honors thesis asks: how does dance help me to remember my name?  And, by remembering my name, how can I better recognize, witness, be with, share with, and dance within a community?  Exploring the intersections of language, movement, and self-identity, Robyn looks at her self-identity within a larger cultural context, pulling from specific American literary texts, which evidence a paradox in the American dominant culture's ethos.  As the creative component to her research questions, Robyn choreographed a dance piece that explores a very personal way of recognizing who she is, what she is a product of, and how her movement patterns have evolved from the rejection of previous power structures within the dance world.</p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    Mind, Language, and Movement  </h3>  
          <p>Theater 144: Sources of Movement<br />English 143B: Verse<br />English 190: Research Seminar<br />Theater 146A: Choreography<br />Theater 146B: Intermediate Dance Technique<br />American Studies H110: The New Literary History of America</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Robyn Taylor</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Robyn%20Taylor.jpg" title="Robyn Taylor " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3411-O4gV201IoZA" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/Robyn%20Taylor.jpg?itok=O9BkUMAf" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>After graduating in May 2013, Robyn Taylor took part in a professional six-week dance intensive workshop in Toubab Dialow, Senegal at Ecole des Sables.  The teaching at this dance workshop consisted of various traditional West African dance forms as well as contemporary dance and choreographic techniques.  Robyn is currently residing in Paris, France where she is studying contemporary dance at Menagerie de Verre.  Fascinated by the movement and ethos of Paris, Robyn observes the metro system, the grocery stores, and various art creations ranging from the highly commercialized to the subversive.  She writes about these observations on her blog.  She is currently collaborating with three dancers and four graffiti artists on a performance piece that will take place in a street artists’ squat December 14.  Next, Robyn will go to Salvador, Bahia, Brazil, where she will continue her dance studies in the Silvestre Technique.  Robyn applied this fall for the Fulbright Fellowship 2014, and in the upcoming year she hopes to continue her investigation of identity and dance in Senegal.  Her Fulbright proposal is titled: "Rhythm in Dakar: The Kinesthetic Exchange of Dance within a Globalized Context."</p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Eli Wirtschafter </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-2528ad42cb76b671abcbf337d6bc079e">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    &quot;Street Theater at Astor Place: Performance on the Nineteenth Century Public Stage&quot;  </h3>  
          <div class="thesis-image"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Wirtschafter-Astor%20Place.png" title="Eli Wirtschafter " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3412-MtVGSKDBLRo" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/medium/public/Wirtschafter-Astor%20Place.png?itok=9hBJaAfa" width="170" height="220" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>The Astor Place Riot, in New York in 1849, was set off by a rivalry between actors: the eminent English tragedian William Macready, and the first American stage star, Edwin Forrest.  When ten thousand rioters and spectators gathered outside the Astor Place Opera House, some booing and throwing stones, the state militia was summoned.  They fired into the crowd, killing at least twenty.</p>
<p>In his honors thesis, Eli Wirtschafter looks at the Astor Place Riot in context with other forms of public behavior, arguing that the clash between rioters and the elite militia paralleled the contest between rowdiness and refinement taking place daily inside the theaters and on the streets.  As working class theatergoers fought a losing battle to maintain the principle of "audience sovereignty," they also struggled to defend the legitimacy of traditional forms of public assembly.  At a time when audience participation was a way of performing identity, a riot was another way to assert ownership of public space.</p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    Visual, Literary, and Performance Cultures  </h3>  
          <p>American Studies H110: The New Literary History of America<br />Theater 125: Performance and History: Stanislavski in Hollywood<br />American Studies C132B: Intellectual History of the United States since 1965<br />History 122AC: Antebellum America: The Advent of Mass Society<br />American Studies H110: American National Character<br />American Studies 102: Theming America</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Eli Wirtschafter</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Eli%20Wirtschafter.jpg" title="Eli Wirtschafter " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3412-MtVGSKDBLRo" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/Eli%20Wirtschafter.jpg?itok=vFtzHeDu" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>The Departmental Citation winner for 2013 for both American Studies and Theater, Dance &amp; Performance Studies, for his honors thesis Eli wrote a historical paper, and wrote and directed a play based on that research.  Eli is currently a reporter for San Francisco's public radio station, KALW.  Tune in to <em>Crosscurrents</em>, weekdays at 5 on 91.7. </p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->
	<div class="clear"></div>

	<!-- Breadcrumb -->
	<!--<div id="breadcrumb-wrap" class="grid_12"><p id="breadcrumbs">You are here: &nbsp; <a href="/">Home</a> &nbsp; &#62;  &nbsp; <a href="/about-major" title="">Major</a> &nbsp; &#62;  &nbsp; <a href="/graduates">Graduate Profiles</a></p></div>-->

	    <div class="clear"></div><div class="clear"></div>    <div class="clear"></div><div class="clear"></div>

	
			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Wendy Bravo </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-056798b53bebb2e4d61430d55d023b67">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    &quot;Growing Justice, Cultivating Change: Food, Race, and the Mandela Farmers&#039; Market In West Oakland, California&quot;  </h3>  
          <p>In light of the growing support for local food movements, led by proponents such as Michael Pollan and Alice Waters, Wendy Bravo utilizes the existence of a unique West Oakland food organization--known collectively as Mandela Marketplace--to explore the historical connection between racial discrimination and the current food injustices seen in many African American neighborhoods.  In "Growing Justice, Cultivating Change," Wendy discusses the role of race and privilege in explaining how institutional policies have decimated the food sovereignty of low-income Americans and also examines various cases of food activism in African American communities throughout the country.</p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    Health and Minority Communities  </h3>  
          <p>Integrative Biology 137: Human Endocrinology<br />Chicano Studies 176: Chicanos and Health Care<br />Public Health 150E: Introduction to Community Health and Human Development<br />Nutritional Sciences 166: Nutrition in the Community<br />Public Health 150B: Introduction to Environmental Health Sciences<br />ESPM 163 AC: Environmental Justice: Race, Class, Equity, and the Environment</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Wendy Bravo</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Wendy%20Bravo.jpg" title="Wendy Bravo " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3413-kEZYMdQCbOg" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/Wendy%20Bravo.jpg?itok=W1D6Rq-C" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>After graduating in December 2012, Wendy began working full-time with Brown &amp; Toland Medical Group in San Francisco.  Her work mainly focuses on analyzing the implementation of accountable care organizations (ACOs)--a new payment method for doctors, where payments are determined by the overall health of a patient, rather than by how many tests or exams a patient received.  Wendy has also continued her volunteer work in community health and soon hopes to become a certified Covered California counselor to help people sign up for health insurance through the state’s health exchange.  Wendy plans on returning to school to complete the requirements for medical school and pursue a career as a primary care doctor.</p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->
	<div class="clear"></div>
	
<!-- Footer -->
  		<footer>
	  		<div id="social-wrap" >
			<div id="social-icons" class="container_12">
			
			<ul class="grid_3">
				<li id="rss">
					<a href="/rss.xml">
						<div class="fadeThis">
							<span class="hover"></span>
						</div>
					</a>
					</li>
			<!-- CONTACT -->
					<li id="contact">
					<a href="contact-information">

	<!--<div id="breadcrumb-wrap" class="grid_12"><p id="breadcrumbs">You are here: &nbsp; <a href="/">Home</a> &nbsp; &#62;  &nbsp; <a href="/about-major" title="">Major</a> &nbsp; &#62;  &nbsp; <a href="/graduates">Graduate Profiles</a></p></div>-->

	    <div class="clear"></div><div class="clear"></div>    <div class="clear"></div><div class="clear"></div>

	
			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">David Swatt </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-1c09bf5646a5b68d758b609f2eba8cc0">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    &quot;From Cornfields to Cadillacs: The Evolution of Beverly Hills&quot;  </h3>  
          <p>David Swatt's senior thesis presents a cultural history of one of the world's most famed cities.  Among central questions examined concerns how land values between Santa Monica Boulevard and Benedict Canyon gained seemingly instantaneous value.  David suggests that a spike in land values can be attributed to the development of the Beverly Hills Hotel and Pickfair.  Also addressed is whether the City's premier amenities followed the wealth or existed prior to the infiltration of society's elite.  David argues that such amenities followed the wealth, and that their purposes was to reinforce the dominant narrative and valuable myth of Beverly Hills as a sanctuary to reside, vacation, and shop.  In comparing past and present-day Beverly Hills David counters the historian Walter Wagner's suggestion that Beverly Hills is a shadow of its former self, contending that its glamorous celebrity residences and exorbitant home prices demonstrate its improvement.  The epilogue uses Lake Forest, Illinois and Great Neck, New York as a comparative lens by which to argue that the trend of premium developments existed throughout America and also to suggest how these communities contributed to a unique narrative of residential elitism.</p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    Environmental Management and Policy  </h3>  
          <p>Geography 130: Food and the Environment<br />ESPM 155: Sociology of Natural Resources<br />American Studies 101: The Birth of Consumerism<br />American Studies 101AC: Age of the City<br />American Studies 102: Theming America<br />ESPM 169: International Environmental Politics</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">David Swatt</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/david%20swatt.png" title="David Swatt " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3414-1UcsqsPzQYs" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/david%20swatt.png?itok=drx2eTHU" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>Since graduation in 2012, David returned to Los Angeles, and began a full-time career selling residential real estate with the highest grossing office in the United States, Coldwell Banker-Beverly Hills North.</p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Ramzi Fawaz </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-c723a2cb824c90ae5fa644388b3b6850">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    &quot;Big Trouble in Smallville: The Rise of the Teenage Superhero in the 20th Century&quot;  </h3>  
          <div class="thesis-image"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/fawaz%20cover.jpg" title="Ramzi Fawaz " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3443-nxfkMhvv3zM" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/medium/public/fawaz%20cover.jpg?itok=em9gRcS_" width="170" height="220" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>Ramzi Fawaz's honors thesis develops a visual history of the teenage superhero in post-WWII American culture. Ramzi argues that the teen superhero became a visual index of key historical crises in the postwar period that were metaphorized in the form of unruly superpowers and biologically unstable bodies, ultimately cathecting particular generational conflicts to the bodies of developing youth gifted with extraordinary abilities. This thesis reconstructs the historical trajectory of the figure across time while also attending to shifting thematic concerns that run across the period of its greatest popularity. By charting the lineage of the thematic concerns of these texts, the cultural diversity of their characters, as well as the villains, dilemmas, and inter-group conflicts that motivated their narratives, Fawaz unpacks an important historical thread of youth culture that continues to affect our popular imagination to this day.</p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    American Popular Culture  </h3>  
          <p>Film 108: Film Genre<br />English C143V: Visual Autobiography<br />English 176: Literature and Popular Culture <br />Sociology C112: Sociology of Religion<br />English 173: Language/Literature of Films<br />American Studies 101: 1939</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Ramzi Fawaz</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/fawaz_full.jpg" title="Ramzi Fawaz " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3443-nxfkMhvv3zM" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/fawaz_full.jpg?itok=fGORulXM" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>The Departmental Citation Winner for 2006, Ramzi Fawaz is an Assistant Professor of English at the University of Wisconsin, Madison. He received his PhD in American Studies from George Washington University. His book, <em>The New Mutants: Superheroes and the Radical Imagination of American Comics</em>, published by NYU Press as part of their series Post-Millennial Pop in January 2016, explores how the American superhero came to embody the political aspirations of racial, gender, and sexual minorities in the post-WWII period. Ramzi is a former fellow of the Social Science Research Council and the Center for Lesbian and Gay Studies, which awarded his manuscript the 2012-2013 CLAGS Fellowship Award for best first book project in LGBT Studies. His essays have been published in <em>American Literature</em>, <em>Callaloo</em>, and <em>Anthropological Quarterly</em>. His next book project develops a new theory of affect through the study of the cultural politics and literary production of Gay Liberation since the 1970s.</p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>

		</div>

	<!-- Breadcrumb -->
	<!--<div id="breadcrumb-wrap" class="grid_12"><p id="breadcrumbs">You are here: &nbsp; <a href="/">Home</a> &nbsp; &#62;  &nbsp; <a href="/about-major" title="">Major</a> &nbsp; &#62;  &nbsp; <a href="/graduates">Graduate Profiles</a></p></div>-->

	    <div class="clear"></div><div class="clear"></div>    <div class="clear"></div><div class="clear"></div>

	
			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Dani Nameth </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-409f4ad56ce349e9f5b6991028c33abf">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    &quot;You Are What You Eat: Finding the Link Between Medicine, Health and the Organic Food Movement&quot;  </h3>  
          <p>As local, sustainable food becomes evermore ubiquitous and eating conscious becomes the new "it" way to live, the phrase "you are what you eat" seems to be appearing more frequently.  Dani uses the origins of the phrase as a starting point to explore the difference between the organic food movement and western medicine.  The organic food movement relies on a rhetoric of health and wellness while western medicine chooses to disregard, for the most part, food and what people choose to put in their bodies.  Her honors thesis ultimately argues that the obesity epidemic will be the turning point in the antithetical relationship between food and medicine that has developed as a symptom of historical development.  Additionally, she argues that the obesity epidemic, as well as the rise in other diet related diseases, might galvanize a true working relationship between the food system and the medical sphere, resulting not only in a more holistic and culture oriented approach to medicine, but also a way to work to prevent diseases in patients instead of merely treating their symptoms.</p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    Food and Culture  </h3>  
          <p>American Studies 110: Research in Food Studies<br />Geography 130: Food and the Environment<br />Nutritional Science 104: Human Food Practices<br />Letters and Science C101: Edible Education<br />American Studies 101: The Birth of Consumer Society<br />Health Studies 104 (EAP): Food Research</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Dani Nameth</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Dani%20Nameth_0.jpg" title="Dani Nameth " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3484-HIZEosLBRe0" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/Dani%20Nameth_0.jpg?itok=YFDYjYvI" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>After finishing her last semester in December of 2012, Dani spent her final academic time abroad in the United Kingdom studying food science at the University of Leeds.  She has recently moved back to Southern California to focus on Clinical and Translational research.  She is currently working as a Public Administrative Analyst for Phase 2 and 3 Clinical trials for novel treatments in both Sarcoma and Lung Cancer.  Dani has also recently been published in the Journal of American Medicine Dermatology for an epidemiological paper looking at the scope of exposure to indoor tanning.  Dani continues to bring food, nutrition, and medicine into conversation working on research that focuses on the role of BMI and overall survival in cancer patients while she applies to medical school.</p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->

	<div class="container_12" id="header" >
		<header>	
		<div class="grid_12" id="logo-new">	
			<!-- Logo Here -->

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Jennifer Schaefer </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-43d499428cda9df4a07d98bafe2a780f">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    &quot;Training for Success: An Educational Experience&quot;  </h3>  
          <div class="thesis-image"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Jen%20Schaefer%20thesis.png" title="Jennifer Schaefer " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3486-_biSUfCH0sw" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/medium/public/Jen%20Schaefer%20thesis.png?itok=gbo8JVkJ" width="197" height="220" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>Jennifer Schaefer's honors thesis includes an autoethnographic written work and a choreographed dance piece exploring and positioning her educational and associated emotional experiences within the sphere of education in America as the eldest of three children--and the only daughter--of an ethnically Chinese Vietnamese immigrant.  Fervently believing the American Dream of social mobility attainable exclusively through education, Jennifer was required to maintain straight A's in school in order to one day become a doctor or lawyer.  The focus on grades and end goals, rather than the process, ultimately left her feeling as if she existed merely as a piece of raw material to be shaped into a profitable product.  By reflection upon events, conversations, and interactions that have occurred throughout her life, Jennifer aims to discover and reveal the workings of Asian American family culture, social mobility in education, society's varying modes of conformity, and creative expression through the medium of dance in what was meant to be her early training for success.  Intersections of such contributing agents in her education then extends to the conversation regarding what it means that her experience took place.</p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    Education in America  </h3>  
          <p>Chicano Studies172: Chicanos and the Education System<br />African American Studies C133A: Race, Identity, and Culture in Urban Schools<br />Education 162A: Teachers' Work<br />Asian American Studies 146: Asian Americans and Education<br />American Studies H110: New Literary History of America<br />Math 151: Mathematics of the Secondary School Curriculum</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Jennifer Schaefer</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Jen%20Schaefer.jpg" title="Jennifer Schaefer " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3486-_biSUfCH0sw" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/Jen%20Schaefer.jpg?itok=efTZaav8" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>Following graduation in May 2013, Jennifer spent a year working as a math tutor and saving money in order to move to Oahu in pursuit of a slower, balanced lifestyle, the Aloha Spirit, and warmer weather.  In Fall 2014, she will begin to work towards a Ph.D. in Mathematics at the University of Hawaii, hoping either to conduct mathematics research or to become a community college professor.  In either case, Jennifer will offer free math tutoring (and possibly dance lessons) to those who are not able to afford it.  She strives to emphasize education for the sake of learning, and to challenge the commodification of education that strictly purports the acquisition of a financially rewarding job.</p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
