			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Anavictoria Avila </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-0817cee3b854f465e76e598aac640f96">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    “The Disposables: An Analysis of Street Memorials and their Implications for Youth Gang Violence and Incarceration among Marginalized Black and Latino Youth”  </h3>  
          <div class="thesis-image"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Avila-Street%20Memorials.png" title="Anavictoria Avila " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3502-efLnVy14BKc" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/medium/public/Avila-Street%20Memorials.png?itok=MzVtUqZT" width="193" height="220" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>While national homicide rates are at a record low, socioeconomically disadvantaged Black and Latino youth experience death rates disproportionately, violently, and at ages far too young.  Anavictoria Avila’s honors thesis centers on literal and figurative premature death among disadvantaged Black and Latino youth through street violence and incarceration.  Her research includes the contexts and stories behind makeshift street memorials in East Oakland and East Anaheim, where she conducted field work.  She considers how street memorials reflect socio-cultural factors as well as criminal and public policy that manufacture premature death for youth in marginalized communities. Anavictoria argues that the premature death of low-income Black and Latino youth is perpetuated by public policy that neglects to consider the racial, political, and social histories that have predetermined the disadvantaged Black and Brown body as disposable, criminal, and unworthy of consideration in legislative and legal decisions.  In response to current intervention methods of cracking down on gangs and crime through mass incarceration, Anavictoria’s honors thesis concludes with an intervention proposal that focuses on human dignity, family, community, education, and youth empowerment.</p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    Family, Violence, and Youth Development  </h3>  
          <p>Anthropology 119: Violence and Human Rights in War and Peace<br />Legal Studies 155: Government and the Family<br />Psychology 131: Developmental Psychopathology <br />Public Health 210B: Adolescent Health<br />Legal Studies 163: Adolescence, Crime, and Juvenile Justice<br />Sociology 130AC: Social Inequalities, American Cultures</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Anavictoria Avila</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Anavictoria%20Avila_0.jpg" title="Anavictoria Avila " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3502-efLnVy14BKc" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/Anavictoria%20Avila_0.jpg?itok=4Fve8Uc8" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>After graduation in May 2014, Anavictoria returned to Southern California to provide post-surgery recovery care for her mother.  She also worked with several community organizations to develop pilot projects for training Anaheim’s youth in civic awareness and engagement.  With the many policy and political changes occurring in the City of Anaheim, Anavictoria wanted to support her community’s youth throughout summer projects so that their voices and concerns influence current policy discussions.  Anavictoria is currently a 2L at Northwestern School of Law, where she hopes to build from the substantive and practical foundation that her American Studies Major provided for serving and advocating for her community.</p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Folasade Scott </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-7c22c48b7578073ab0a830189ca67843">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    &quot;The Pedagogy of Motivation Part 1: Motivating African-American Disadvantaged Adults Learning Basic Skills through Relationship and Relevance&quot;  </h3>  
          <p>"The Pedagogy of Motivation Part 1" is about the benefits of utilizing relevant means and relational connection to motivate disadvantaged African-American learners of basic skills, many of whom came from troubled backgrounds, such as a broken home, abuse and neglect, drug and alcohol abuse, incarceration, etc. Many were not even encouraged much for success in school, let alone life. While the focus is on disadvantaged African-American adults, Folasade Scott’s thesis is meant to provoke thought and consideration with regard to teaching anyone.  Folasade emphasizes the need to view students as people first—valuable, multifaceted human beings with interests, culture(s), personalities, learning styles, skills, experiences, etc.—and to create and maintain an environment that is community-centered, restorative, and engages all these integral parts of them. In her thesis Folasade asserts that unconditional love and care must be the "basic skills" modeled through educators and cultivated within the classroom which, as a result, will produce favorable responses and encourage positive character outcomes, no matter how wounded a person is. "The Pedagogy of Motivation Part 2" is in progress, and will focus on the application of principles from "Part 1."</p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    The Mind, the Arts, and Education in America  </h3>  
          <p>American Studies C174: Visual Autobiography<br />Sociology 150: Social Psychology<br />Psychology 150: Psychology of Personality<br />Education 197: Field Studies in Education<br />African American Studies 159: Special Topics in African American Literature<br />Music 128S: Contemporary Improvisational Music</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Folasade Scott</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Folasade%20Scott.jpeg" title="Folasade Scott " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3503-fgOokl6jguU" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/Folasade%20Scott.jpeg?itok=ShLHJnAS" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>Since 2009 Folasade has been privileged to enrich people’s lives as a minister, teacher, counselor, and mentor, serving in various parts of the US, as well as Jamaica and Haiti; she has also remotely served people in other countries such as Qatar, Pakistan, Kenya, and Canada. Folasade specializes in restoration and development of the whole person; authentic identity expression; basic and academic life skills development; global community awareness and service; sustainability; and creative expression. She also serves as a consultant and collaborator with organizations and individuals who desire to enrich people’s lives holistically. These services are expressed through two business entities that Folasade founded and directs: a non-profit corporation called Violent Faith Ministries International Inc. and a for-profit business called Redeeming the Time. Folasade is currently completing a Master's program at Winston-Salem State University called Teaching English as a Second Language and Applied Linguistics; she plans to pursue a PhD in Educational Psychology at Georgia State University.</p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Mykiyaa Walker-Sanchez </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-39059410a82233e9663ce09e1bf66b82">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    &quot;Closing the Gap: The Institutionalization of Diabetes in America&quot;  </h3>  
          <p>Mykiyaa Walker-Sanchez’s thesis aims to understand the how structural, environmental, and cultural factors put Black women at higher risk of obesity than white women.  By looking closely at health outcomes in Los Angeles county, Mykiyaa’s thesis analyzes how macro level disparities are reproduced and perpetuated at the local level.</p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    Race, Healthcare, and Urban Communities  </h3>  
          <p>Anthropology 115: Introduction to Medical Anthropology<br />African American Studies 116: Slavery and African American Life before 1865<br />City and Regional Planning 118AC: The Urban Community<br />City and Regional Planning 115: Urbanization in Developing Countries<br />Communication as a Social Force 124: Black Women, Feminism, and the Media<br />Urban Studies and Planning 104: Ethnic Diversity and the City</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Mykiyaa Walker-Sanchez</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Mykiyaa%20Walker-Sanchez.jpg" title="Mykiyaa Walker-Sanchez " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3504-NJ8UmFh8_HU" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/Mykiyaa%20Walker-Sanchez.jpg?itok=5YF-4Ot4" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>After graduating in May 2014, Mykiyaa Walker-Sanchez returned home to her first love, Los Angeles, where she spent the summer volunteering at Residential Care Facilities in urban communities and working with adults with developmental disabilities.   With future professional plans to promote positive well being through good health practices in disadvantaged communities of color and to dismantle some of the socioeconomic barriers that disproportionately affect communities of color, Mykiyaa will pursue a career in medicine as an internal medicine physician. She is currently completing a pre-medicine post-baccalaureate program.</p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->
	<div class="clear"></div>

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Patty Chen </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-29d67d9ef057263e9eae201cf27f8ad5">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    &quot;The Racial Implications of Neoliberal Discourse: How the Stereotype of African Americans as Welfare Recipients and Asian Americans as the Model Minority Support Neoliberalism&quot;  </h3>  
          <div class="thesis-image"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Chen-Racial%20Implications%20of%20Neoliberal%20Discourse.png" title="Patty Chen " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3505-YM303uZvce0" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/medium/public/Chen-Racial%20Implications%20of%20Neoliberal%20Discourse.png?itok=OELTHp18" width="180" height="220" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>In her honors thesis, Patty Chen argues that the presentation of African Americans as poor welfare dependents and Asian Americans as the successful model minority supports the neoliberal notion that a person's individual choice is the determining factor in their economic success or failure in America. Patty argues that these two images obscure the reality of racial meaning and the existence of institutional forces that influence the lives of people of color. This leads to an ineffective discussions concerning how race affects the lives of people of color—discussions that focus on whether racism exists rather than meaningful ways to bridge the gap in the life experiences of people of color and whites.</p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    Race, Ethnicity, and Nation  </h3>  
          <p>Asian American Studies 121: Chinese American History<br />Rhetoric 152AC: Race and Order in the New Republic<br />American Studies 139AC: US Social Movements<br />African American Studies 111: Race, Class, and Gender in the US<br />American Studies H110: American Studies Honors Seminar<br />Ethnic Studies 144AC: Interracial Justice at Law</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Patty Chen</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Patty%20Chen.jpg" title="Patty Chen " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3505-YM303uZvce0" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/Patty%20Chen.jpg?itok=EPdOd-WN" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>Patty spent the summer after graduation studying for the LSAT and working.  She assisted a lawyer doing every day tasks, such as preparing documents to file in court and maintaining an organized electronic and physical copy of all documents to ensure accurate filing of all documents that relate to the cases the firm worked on.  She is currently a 2L at UCLA School of Law.</p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->
	<div class="clear"></div>

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Alexander Lee-Thomas </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-fdb23659373990b9ba25ccacef08d6eb">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    Between the Lines: Where Intersectionality and &quot;The Read&quot; Meet  </h3>  
          <div class="thesis-image"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Lee-Thomas%20-%20Between%20the%20Lines.png" title="Alexander Lee-Thomas " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3554-ZvxMjQEz9j0" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/medium/public/Lee-Thomas%20-%20Between%20the%20Lines.png?itok=y0lla4eg" width="170" height="220" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p class="Body">In his thesis Alexander Lee-Thomas applies Black feminist and quare theory to the popular podcast, <em>The Read</em>.  Through close textual analysis of Kid Fury and Crissle's responses to contemporary racial, political, economic, and cultural events, Alexander explores the unfixed nature of identity and its intersections with oppression.</p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    Race and Representation  </h3>  
          <p>African American Studies 139: Malcolm X</p>
<p>African American Studies 153: Toni Morrison</p>
<p>African American Studies 142AC: Race and American Film</p>
<p>American Studies H110: The Secret History of America</p>
<p>Film 104S: British Film</p>
<p>Music 102S: UK Music and Public Relations</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Alexander Lee-Thomas</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Alexander%20Lee-Thomas.jpg" title="Alexander Lee-Thomas " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3554-ZvxMjQEz9j0" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/Alexander%20Lee-Thomas.jpg?itok=Lar-7J32" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>After graduation, Alexander returned to southern California to spend time with family and pursue internships.  In the Fall of 2015, he will enter the Peter Stark Producing Program at USC's School of Cinematic Arts.  With an MFA, Alexander will work in television and film to increase representation of people of color and "create a new wave in motion pictures."</p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->
	<div class="clear"></div>

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Allison Wallace </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-bb324c82c3fc732536c3d425049f9c91">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    The Corporeality of Contraception: Reading Degeneracy, Resistance, and Nation through the Body in The Birth Control Review  </h3>  
          <p>In her honors thesis, <em>The Corporeality of Contraception</em>, Allison interrogates Margaret Sanger’s seminal reproductive rights magazine, <em>The Birth Control Review</em>. Utilizing Black feminist theory and body scholarship, she examines how the body is manipulated in early 20th century reproductive rights discourse to service different projects: as a political tool to defend white women’s reproductive autonomy, as an object of resistance against racial oppression, as well as a legible text for eugenicists to discern which individuals are “fit” to make up the nation. The vignettes in the <em>Review</em> ultimately illustrate the disturbing alliance between white feminists and eugenicists, as both communities worked to demarcate which bodies were desirable and at the fore of national “progress” and which “abject” bodies required violent erasure.</p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    Race, Gender, and the American Body  </h3>  
          <p>American Studies 101: The Atomic Age</p>
<p>Gender and Women's Studies 142: Women in the Muslim and Arab Worlds</p>
<p>African American Studies 144: Cultural Studies</p>
<p>American Studies H110: Honors Seminar: More than One Country: On Being and Belonging in America</p>
<p>American Studies H110: Honors Seminar: Chicano/Latino Art/Literature in Its Place: Los Angeles, Albuquerque, New York</p>
<p>Gender and Women's Studies 129: Bodies and Boundaries</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Allison Wallace</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Allison%20Wallace_pic.jpg" title="Allison Wallace " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3555-NiRxtFFGuBA" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/Allison%20Wallace_pic.jpg?itok=5lfHOU3z" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>After graduation, Allison began working full-time at nonprofit that helps low-income students earn four-year degrees. As a Development and Communications Coordinator, Allison writes grants, crafts promotional material, and supports all philanthropic engagement activities. Though Allison no longer writes cultural studies papers, she thinks about questions of race, nationhood, gender, belonging, and bodies (among other American Studies topics) daily.</p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Tommy Statkiewicz </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-193d21eff8a4a3e533e5f50e1b5e1d52">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    Trans*Undocu in America: An Intersectional Dream  </h3>  
          <p>While there has been an increasing focus on transgender and undocumented communities in the last two decades, there has been limited focus on the intersectionality of the two identities, referred to as trans*undocu within Tommy Statkiewicz's honors thesis. The current attention on trans*undocu women from Mexico and Central America in detention centers deserves awareness and immediate action, but many more trans*undocu individuals from various countries of origin and points on the transgender spectrum need to be heard as well. However, this is not just a trans*undocu issue; injustices experienced by trans*undocu individuals are also experienced by the larger American society. Trans*undocu individuals face racial profiling, are denied health benefits, are targets of violence and sexual harassment, and face family rejection, among other obstacles that each American can relate to because it has happened to them or someone they know. And yet despite the layered hurdles faced by trans*undocu individuals, their resilience to live life authentically and their desire to take part in the American Dream too is shared by each American. This narrative cannot be ignored because the trans*undocu story is an American story.</p>
<p> </p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    Intersectionality in American Social and Cultural Spaces  </h3>  
          <p>Education 195C: Special Topics in the Foundations of Teaching</p>
<p>Education 130: Knowing and Learning in Mathematics and Science</p>
<p>American Studies H110: Honors Seminar: Imagining America</p>
<p>American Studies 182E: Urban Field Geography of San Francisco</p>
<p>Architecture 110AC: The Social and Cultural Basis of Design</p>
<p>Gender and Women's Studies 129: Bodies and Boundaries</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Tommy Statkiewicz</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/StatkiewiczT_2015_Picture%20for%20AS%20Website.jpg" title="Tommy Statkiewicz " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3556-hdrCyQKVdu8" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/StatkiewiczT_2015_Picture%20for%20AS%20Website.jpg?itok=2zGA1VWj" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>UC Berkeley and the American Studies department have afforded Tommy a newfound voice and confidence that he graciously embodies. While he finalized his senior honors thesis on trans*undocu individuals in America, Tommy apprenticed on three local queer films to indulge his creative instinct. He also completed his Board of Immigration Appeals Level 1 Accredited Representative status with Educators for Fair Consideration (E4FC) and was hired as their Legal Services Coordinator in June of 2015. Tommy plans to attend law school in the fall of 2017 so that he may continue empowering and supporting LGBTQ and undocumented communities. Tommy feels fortunate to have the support of his wife, Clara Mae, with whom he loves exploring the American landscape via road trips and someday plans to travel beyond U.S. borders.</p>
<p> </p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>

		<div id="copyright-wrap">	
			<div class="container_12">
			<div id="copyright" class="grid_12 omega">
			
						
			  <div class="region region-footer-copyright">

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Sophia Ng </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-dcb176d65c0559d30c1be93abc1c1e2a">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    Channels for Change: Sesame Street’s Ability to Implement Civil Rights Ideology in Children’s Programming  </h3>  
          <p>Sophia Ng’s honors thesis, “Channels for Change: <em>Sesame Street</em>’s Ability to Implement Civil Rights Ideology in Children’s Programming,” investigates the interplay between television and the civil rights era. Television played an important role to capture and circulate images of war, rebellion, and social change throughout the United States in the 1960s. Her honors thesis asks, how was America’s changing social landscape portrayed on television to the nation’s most nascent demographic-- preschoolers?  Sophia’s thesis explores this question within the context of the children’s program, <em>Sesame Street, </em>a show known for its lovable puppets, educational content, and integrated urban setting. <em>Sesame Street </em>first aired in 1969, a turbulent year when television was dominated by news of the first man on the moon, the Stonewall Riot in New York City, and the beginning of Nixon’s “Vietnamization” of Southeast Asia. Juxtaposing these social realities against <em>Sesame Street</em>, a show that welcomed American youth into an inner city utopia, Sophia draws upon examples, such as Jesse Jackson’s recitation of “I Am Somebody” and songs like “Bein’ Green” and “People In Your Neighborhood,” and explores the ways in which <em>Sesame Street </em>sought to normalize values of justice and inclusivity on the small screen.</p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    Twentieth Century American Culture  </h3>  
          <p>Asian American Studies 171: Asian Americans in Film and Video</p>
<p>American Studies 102: The Road in American Culture</p>
<p>History 124B: The United States from World War II to the Vietnam Era</p>
<p>History C139AC: Civil Rights and Social Movements in U.S. History</p>
<p>Ethnic Studies 176: Ethnic Art and Artists</p>
<p>American Studies 2029 (University of Hong Kong): Current Perspectives on the U.S.</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Sophia Ng</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Sophia%20Ng_photo.JPG" title="Sophia Ng " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3557-1elm4hl47cM" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/Sophia%20Ng_photo.JPG?itok=2Crn-ppu" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>After graduating, Sophia Ng worked at Kickstarter in New York City as an Integrity Analyst.  She also served as a Board Member for the National Asian Pacific American Women’s Forum*New York City (NAPAWF*NYC) chapter, where she volunteered her time working on reproductive justice, immigrant rights, and worker advocacy issues.  Sophia is currently a Fulbright Teaching Assistant, teaching English at a secondary school in Gopeng, Perak in Malaysia.</p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->
	<div class="clear"></div>

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Shabnam Banerjee-McFarland </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-8bc8c30b9bcea3e8e4b18584400c1678">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    Racial Formations In New York Fashion Week under the Obama Era  </h3>  
          <p>In an industry that walks the fine line of seemingly shallow aesthetics and class-designated "conspicuous consumption," Shabnam Banerjee-McFarland's thesis asks how does the New York Fashion Industry affect the way we see race? New York fashion houses, such as Ralph Lauren and Tommy Hilfiger, are arguably some of the most subversive corporate brands in thinking about the politics of beauty, race, and the visual aesthetic due to their constant attempts to steer clear of politics. Shabnam's thesis deconstructs standards of American beauty, and the ways in which the New York fashion industry cultivates these standards during New York Fashion Week. There is a highly decisive performance that aims to perpetuate white femininity, where whiteness is unmarked and reigns supreme. Subsequently, women of color are routinely compared and contrasted to this paradigm through exoticizing and fetishizing their bodies, ultimately resulting in their erasure. She juxtaposes <em>Vogue</em>'s photo-series entitled "Street Style," or photography captured of those attending the event (fashion bloggers, designers, photographers, journalists, etc) against the meticulously styled models captured on the runway. Representation, as always, matters.</p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    Politics of Cultural Representation  </h3>  
          <p>American Studies 101: The Birth of Consumer Society in the U.S.</p>
<p>American Studies 101: American Culture in the Atomic Age</p>
<p>African American Studies 142AC: Race and American Film</p>
<p>Media Studies 104A: Freedom of Speech and the Press</p>
<p>American Studies 102: Cultures of Place: California Food</p>
<p>History 125A: <span class="st">The History of Black People and Race Relations, 1550-1861</span></p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Shabnam Banerjee-McFarland</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/shabnam%20banerjee-mcfarland.jpg" title="Shabnam Banerjee-McFarland " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3558-w57bvrnnPG8" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/shabnam%20banerjee-mcfarland.jpg?itok=8hNeLHFS" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>After a series of trial-and-error attempts to start a career in fashion retail and marketing, Shabnam Banerjee-McFarland did a 180 turn and channeled her energy into working with non-profits and learning more about the importance of disseminating change-making policy in all popular culture channels. Since January 2015, she has been working in book marketing with Berrett-Koehler Publishers, a mission-based publishing company in Oakland, CA that publishes books on social justice, conscious capitalism, and self-help in order to "Create a World That Works For All." Most recently, she is designing an extensive research program to confront the extreme lack of diversity in publishing, in hopes of elevating voices from communities that are underrepresented in the industry. A true SF native through and through, Shabnam continues to fight to maintain the colorful vibrancy of San Francisco &amp; Oakland by writing for her personal blog and the Berrett-Koehler blog.</p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>

		</div>

	<!-- Breadcrumb -->
	<!--<div id="breadcrumb-wrap" class="grid_12"><p id="breadcrumbs">You are here: &nbsp; <a href="/">Home</a> &nbsp; &#62;  &nbsp; <a href="/about-major" title="">Major</a> &nbsp; &#62;  &nbsp; <a href="/graduates">Graduate Profiles</a></p></div>-->

	    <div class="clear"></div><div class="clear"></div>    <div class="clear"></div><div class="clear"></div>

	
			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Neha Goel </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-0d97f83013f3891b5307aab8aa489128">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    From East to West, Whiteness Is the Best: A Cultural Analysis of How South Asians Attain Social Status in America  </h3>  
          <p>In her senior honors thesis, Neha presents a larger discussion between two culturally distinct countries, India and America, that both suffer from problems of racism that similarly exhibit themselves through an internalized desire for whiteness as a means of gaining social status. She first notes how this desire for whiteness amongst South Asians is manifested physically through the socially pathogenic skin bleaching phenomenon and then shifts the conversation over to the American landscape to argue that Indian Americans have turned away from this physical demonstration of lightness in order to attain their own form of whiteness. In order to gain the same levels of social status, socioeconomic status, and social advancement that is associated with skin lightening practices in India, South Asian Americans are engaging in social, rather than physical, practices of whitening through an adherence to the model minority stereotype and through promotions of anti-Black racism. In order to accomplish this feat, Neha critically analyzed various cultural mediums, such as social media platforms, television shows, advertisements, literature, psychological research, and anthropological studies to provide evidence for her case.</p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    Race, Politics, and Culture   </h3>  
          <p>American Studies H110: Imagining America</p>
<p>English 166AC: Race and Performance</p>
<p>Ethnic Studies 100: Comparative Ethnic Literature in America</p>
<p>Gender and Women's Studies 129: Bodies and Boundaries</p>
<p>Psychology 166AC: Cultural Psychology</p>
<p>Psychology 167AC: Stigma and Prejudice</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Neha Goel</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/neha%20goel.png" title="Neha Goel " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3579-_afcKYv7blI" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/neha%20goel.png?itok=iHdc-wLJ" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>After graduation, Neha, a double major in American Studies and Psychology, moved to the other side of the Bay to serve as the Project Manager for the Healthy Body Image Study at Stanford University and Palo Alto University. This clinical psychology research study aims to improve body image culture on college campuses by offering a suite of programs that are designed to prevent and treat the onset of eating disorder symptomology amongst college women. Neha hopes to attend a clinical psychology doctoral program in the Fall of 2017 and will utilize the racial, social, and political awareness that she gained from her American Studies courses in her future work as a clinician. Neha’s ultimate goal is to work at the intersection of cultural and clinical psychology in order to address the stigma of mental health that affects all individuals, most especially people of color. </p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->

	<div id="top-bg"></div>
	<div class="container_12" id="header" >
		<header>	
		<div class="grid_12" id="logo-new">	
			<!-- Logo Here -->

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Isis Dillard </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-7c578563d6e48ca17d8f4076940fce3f">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    &quot;Just Say No!&quot;: The War on Drugs in the Reagan Era and the Privilege of Choice  </h3>  
          <div class="thesis-image"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/dillard%20thesis%20cover.png" title="Isis Dillard " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3580-KBhjJ0SDasA" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/medium/public/dillard%20thesis%20cover.png?itok=iG-Nr5f-" width="169" height="220" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>A moral panic erupted in the 1980s when stories about crack cocaine saturated the American media.  Isis's thesis outlines social thought about drugs and drug use in the 1980s, explores medical opinion about drug use, compares how policy and law were developed, analyzes propaganda depicting Black women as drug abusers, and ultimately develops a deep historical reading of the emergence and effects of the "Just Say No!" campaign. In her thesis, Isis argues that the campaign's slogan and practices reflect a "pick yourself up by your bootstraps" mentality that is embedded in American culture and that is directly reified in structural inequality.</p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    Politics, Law, and Race  </h3>  
          <p>African American Studies W124: Political Philosophy of Martin Luther King</p>
<p>African American Studies 139: African American Social Organizations and Institutions</p>
<p>African American Studies 139: Education</p>
<p>American Studies H110: More than One Country: On Being and Belonging in America</p>
<p>American Studies H110: American Rebels and Revolutionaries</p>
<p>Gender and Women's Studies 130AC: Gender, Race, Nation, and Health</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Isis Dillard</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Isis%20Dillard.png" title="Isis Dillard " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3580-KBhjJ0SDasA" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/Isis%20Dillard.png?itok=RIanajB6" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>After graduation, Isis plans to build a career that excites her passion for communication, digital marketing, and social media. Starting January 2016, she will be working full time as a Market Development Representative for a technical recruitment company called TalentBin in San Francisco.  Isis's ultimate academic goal is to return to school in 2018 to pursue a Master's of Business Administration and a Master's of Public Administration. These degrees will allow her to make a practical impact on how business institutions intersect with ideas of race, sex, class, gender, and disability.</p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Kelly Naze </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-1f29286ac5a0285d6fc9bfcb6af929bb">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    “Amusing Some of the Million at Musée Mécanique: The Unpromising Fate of Penny-Arcade Museums in the 21st Century”  </h3>  
          <div class="thesis-image"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Thesiscovershot.png" title="Kelly Naze " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3611-TABsHrDD5AQ" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/medium/public/Thesiscovershot.png?itok=JSHxmVLi" width="172" height="220" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>Exploring how Musée Mécanique, a penny-arcade museum in San Francisco, embodies aspects of Coney Island at the turn of the 20<sup>th</sup> century, Kelly Naze’s senior honors thesis unpacks the cultural fascination with machines, the mystery of objects that re-imagine turn-of-the-century pleasure parks, and the deleterious effects of contemporary consumerism on such mechanical memories.</p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    American Consumer Society  </h3>  
          <p>American Studies 101: The Birth of Consumerism</p>
<p>American Studies H110: Rebels and Revolutionaries</p>
<p>Demography C126: <span class="st">Social Consequences of Population Dynamics</span></p>
<p>Information C167: Virtual Communities/Social Media</p>
<p>Sociology 160: Sociology of Culture</p>
<p>Sociology 166: Society &amp; Technology</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Kelly Naze</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/NazeKelly.jpg" title="Kelly Naze " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3611-TABsHrDD5AQ" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/NazeKelly.jpg?itok=AO9Sjkow" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>After graduating with honors and ending a lifelong swimming career, Kelly returned home to Denver, Colorado, where she will put her competitive spirit and passion for planning to work as she starts her own business as a wedding planner.</p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->
	<div class="clear"></div>

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Vanessa Padilla </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-f03098d0dc2457722f5eb7d122a0396a">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    &quot;A Tale of Two Cities: Richmond, California and Flint, Michigan&quot;  </h3>  
          <div class="thesis-image"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/padilla%20thesis%20cover.png" title="Vanessa Padilla " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3612-1SlhzOjhtrs" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/medium/public/padilla%20thesis%20cover.png?itok=Pri4Ppbd" width="170" height="220" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>Vanessa Padilla’s senior thesis borrows themes from Charles Dickens’s timeless novel, <em>A Tale of Two Cities</em>, to understand the disproportionate environmental burdens carries by communities of color in Richmond, California and Flint, Michigan. Focusing on the water crisis in Flint and the toxic air pollution in Richmond, Vanessa’s comparative interdisciplinary thesis unpacks the history of each crisis against a backdrop of scientific data, media representation, political rhetoric, and private corruption.</p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    Urban Communities and Education  </h3>  
          <p>African American Studies C133: Race, Identity, and Culture in Urban Schools</p>
<p>Chicano Studies 159 : Mexican Immigration</p>
<p>Chicano Studies 172: Chicanos and the Educational System</p>
<p>Education 140AC: Literacy: Individual and Societal Development</p>
<p>Education 190: Critical Studies in Education</p>
<p>Sociology 130AC: Social Inequalities: American Cultures</p>
<p> </p>
<p> </p>
<p> </p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Vanessa Padilla</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/vanessa%20padilla2.png" title="Vanessa Padilla " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3612-1SlhzOjhtrs" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/vanessa%20padilla2.png?itok=X5VB2AbP" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>The summer after graduation Vanessa immersed herself in French language and culture while living in Paris.  On her return to the states, Vanessa continues to intern for Congresswoman Nancy Pelosi, serving constituents in San Francisco.  Vanessa plans to pursue a degree in environmental law, so that she can advocate for people who face environmental crises like those she addressed in her senior thesis.</p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Alec Kassin </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-1dbb5d4dbeebede5a15652e2280c3a31">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    &quot;Caught Stealing: The Major League Baseball Players Association — A Union for the Few at the Expense of the Many&quot;  </h3>  
          <p>With $3.5 billion to divide between roughly 1,200 baseball players each year, the Major League Baseball Players Association (MLBPA) is described by members and scholars as the most powerful union in the country. When the then-ineffective MLBPA was founded in 1953, private sector unionization was at its zenith. Today, the MLBPA is at the height of its power at a time when private sector unionization has hit a nadir, with a mere 6.6% of Americans unionized, down from a peak of 35% in the 1950s. In this context it can be tempting to regard the MLBPA as a formidable outlier that has successfully bucked the trend of deunionization, but the reality is far less uplifting. To achieve success, the MLBPA has actually repressed low-level workers within the same industry, thereby creating a microcosm of our current era — the New Gilded Age, defined by a growing divide between rich and poor — in professional baseball. This repression has come in the form of restricting minor league player rights and is exemplified by the union’s actions during the 1994-1995 player strike, the rollback of baseball’s antitrust exemption, and changes to the format of the amateur draft. At the same time, a shift from policies that benefit the largest number of players to ones that favor superstars has resulted in rampant individualism within the baseball world and has perhaps been to the detriment of the well-being of the union. Alec Kassin's senior honors thesis illustrates how a large concentration of labor power shared only by a few select workers within an industry can be just as problematic for lower level worker rights as a large concentration of corporate power.</p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    Policy, Politics, and Sport in the U.S.  </h3>  
          <p><span class="st">Business Administration 196: Sports Marketing</span></p>
<p>Education 290B: <span class="st">Education in Language, Literacy, and Culture</span></p>
<p>History 124B: <span class="st">The United States from World War II to the Vietnam Era</span></p>
<p><span class="st">Political Science 103: Congress</span></p>
<p><span class="st">Political Science 106A: <span class="st">American Politics: Campaign Strategy - Media</span></span></p>
<p><span class="st">Public Policy C103: Wealth and Poverty</span></p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Alec Kassin</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/alec%20kassin.png" title="Alec Kassin " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3613-b1ummUKQ8bY" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/alec%20kassin.png?itok=8onxI43p" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>Alec, the Departmental Citation recipient for 2016, graduated with Highest Honors after a longer-than-expected college career, marked by a high of spending a year studying abroad in France, and a low of taking a year off from Berkeley due to a back injury. In the summer after his graduation, he plans to work as a camp counselor for an American-style summer camp in Japan, helping Japanese youth learn English by participating in American sports. In October, he will begin work in LinkedIn's Business Leadership Program, rotating through multiple sales units before taking on a full-time role in their Global Sales Organization. Though his long-term plans are unclear (they may consist of a return to academia to earn a Master's in Public Policy, a run for political office, or both), Alec’s ultimate goal is to have a career through which he can find fulfillment helping others. Right now, Alec is engrossed in learning about the causes, effects, and possible solutions to widening inequality in American society.</p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>

	    <div class="clear"></div><div class="clear"></div>    <div class="clear"></div><div class="clear"></div>

	
			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Sha Quasha Morgan </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-ccefb51a029a7dce1373e4df43f9a142">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    &quot;I Can Do Bad All by Myself: Stigma of Mental Illness, Power, Pedagogy, Black Masculinity and America&#039;s Healthcare System&quot;  </h3>  
          <p>Sha Quasha’s senior thesis explores the significant and misunderstood relationship between power, health and race. Focusing on the complex constructions of Black masculinity and its interactions with history, language, and media representation, she unpacks how particular social identities must navigate society and health care, specifically whether or now and how to pursue mental health care.  Sha Quasha demonstrates how discursive practices are used to create and perpetuate racialized mental health disparities, and argues that Black men’s reluctance to seek mental health care is not simply a matter of individual choice, but their decisions are largely shaped by external forces.  </p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    Race, Culture, and Health  </h3>  
          <p>African American Studies 111: <span class="st">Race, Class, and Gender in the United States</span></p>
<p>Public Health C155: Sociology of Health and Medicine</p>
<p>Psychology 166AC: Cultural Psychology</p>
<p>Sociology 110: Organizations and Social Institutions</p>
<p>Sociology 131AC: <span class="st">Race and Ethnic Relations: U.S. American Cultures</span></p>
<p>Social Welfare 110: Social Work as a Profession</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Sha Quasha Morgan</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/sha%20quasha%20morgan.png" title="Sha Quasha Morgan " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3614-4vhuwrGqaY4" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/sha%20quasha%20morgan.png?itok=WootfTJy" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>Because she is passionate about being a model for success for students that come from the same background, Sha Quasha will pursue counseling for low income, first generation college students. Following summer, Sha Quasha hopes to work either as a College and Career Counselor in the Oakland Unified School District or as an Academic Advisor within the community college system. Subsequently, she plans to pursue a Master’s in Social Work with an emphasis on either Child and Family Welfare or Community Mental Health. Sha Quasha’s ultimate goal is to provide more awareness to her community about the mental health issues that adversely affect them and necessary support. </p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Daniel Acree </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-dd8a2843f91a453fd7588c131cfad9e0">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    &quot;Cinematic American Tough: Evolution Of Inclusion From The Cold War To The Millennial Era&quot;  </h3>  
          <p>Hollywood movies are like blueprints that show the construction of the American character. In his thesis, Daniel uses an interdisciplinary approach to motion pictures and traces the evolution of cinematic American tough, from the Cold War era (1945-1991) of exclusion, to the present day (2016) of growing inclusion. He continues the scholarly argument that some movies can be, and have been, used to build togetherness, equity, empathy, altruism, and inclusion of American tough amongst the ever expanding globalized <em>Communitas</em>. However, as Daniel’s research into Hollywood’s cinematic American tough images, meanings and representations progressed, he discovered that more popular and mass produced films, especially during the Cold War era, were used to (1) create, promulgate and reinforce socially constructed ideologies of patriarchy, misogyny, racism, ageism, homophobia, xenophobia, and bigotry, (2) define, regulate and make American masculinity exclusive to white heterosexual males, and (3) manufacture generations of primed Americans nostalgic for a whiter America.</p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    Gender and American Popular Culture  </h3>  
          <p>African American Studies 142AC: Race and American Film</p>
<p>American Studies 101: The Short American Century: From World War II to the New Frontier, 1942-1963</p>
<p>American Studies H110: Rebels and Revolutionaries</p>
<p>Education 183: High School, The Movie</p>
<p>Gender and Women's Studies 100AC: Women in American Culture</p>
<p>Peace and Conflict Studies 127: <span class="st">Human Rights and Global Politics</span></p>
<p> </p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Daniel Acree</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/danny%20acree.png" title="Daniel Acree " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3615-HnLnjAskQzU" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/danny%20acree.png?itok=ssZC_WaK" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>As a graduating Student Veteran still attached to the U.S. Army Reserves, Staff Sergeant Acree continues his personal mission to provide his comrades, as well as all others, with improved life chances by advocating for higher education. Daniel is pursuing a single-subject teaching credential with a Master’s in Education at the University of California, Davis. He would like to be a lifelong thinker, joker, educator, and organizer. Daniel and his partner, Alayna Fredricks, enjoy their happy little life and home in sunny wherever-the-road-leads, California.</p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Catherine O&amp;#039;Neal </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-7a101eb3ce340ce11d5e3aa9ae1696ed">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    &quot;Taking a Trip: The Road, Drugs, and Americans&quot;  </h3>  
          <p>Cat's senior thesis explores the relationship between cannabis and popular and counter cultures, as it provides the key to understanding the bipolar perceptions of marijuana in the United States. Legally, Americans envision cannabis as taboo, but in popular culture Americans relate marijuana to freedom, youth and community. As such, cannabis use became a physical way to express overt protest and dissatisfaction with American institutions. As many artists, musicians and writers romanticized and glamorized marijuana, a disenchanted young generation followed suit and sought refuge with cannabis, helping turn marijuana's illegality into a political and cultural war.</p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    American Popular Culture  </h3>  
          <p>American Studies C118: The American Teenager</p>
<p>American Studies 101: The Atomic Age &amp; Nuclear Criticism</p>
<p>American Studies 110: Folklore and American Culture</p>
<p>American Studies C118: Consumerism and Popular Culture</p>
<p>American Studies H110: Honors Seminar on American National Character</p>
<p>Sociology 160: The Sociology of Culture</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Catherine O&#039;Neal</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Catherine%20O%27Neal.jpg" title="Catherine O&amp;#039;Neal " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3616-tTHRJcbf924" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/Catherine%20O%27Neal.jpg?itok=tmGTMDWV" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>Since graduation in 2007 Catherine has kept herself busy in an array of activities from working in museums to Latin America travels.  After years of managing the Lululemon store in Berkeley, she currently resides in Austin, Texas, where she works as a bartender and yoga instructor.</p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->

	    <div class="clear"></div><div class="clear"></div>    <div class="clear"></div><div class="clear"></div>

	
			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Adrienne Johnson </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-f103cb66be844d99feb2c22de2038ee9">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    &quot;Talking with Their Mouths Full: Competitive Eating and the Cultural Meaning of American Bodies&quot;  </h3>  
          <div class="thesis-image"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/johnson%20cover.jpg" title="Adrienne Johnson " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3617-g2NmJL8QMoc" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/medium/public/johnson%20cover.jpg?itok=IuDHuLok" width="189" height="220" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>Adrienne Johnson's honors thesis is an examination of the story we tell ourselves about ourselves in an eating contest.  While competitive eating today traces its roots back to early American pie-eating contests, the current level of prize money and professionalism point not to a flippant exercise in public ridicule, but to a performance of great cultural meaning.  Using the three distinct scholarly approaches of history, anthropology, and gender studies, Adrienne's research uncovers the tensions of American assimilation, consumerism, and patriarchy.  The performative body of the competitive eater is just one of the many texts this research has drawn upon; a series of interviews with competitive eaters, fat activists, and audience members have offered personal understanding while the scholarship of theorists and anthropologists like Mikhail Bakhtin have grounded the research into the academic literature of cultural performance.</p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    Consumer Society &amp; Contemporary American Culture  </h3>  
          <p>Sociology 180: American Society</p>
<p>Anthropology 162: American Folklore</p>
<p>Geography 181: Urban Field Study</p>
<p>American Studies C112B: American Cultural Landscapes, 1900 to the Present</p>
<p>History of Art 192AC: American Folk Art</p>
<p>American Studies 250: Graduate Research Seminar in American Studies</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Adrienne Johnson</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Adrienne%20Johnson.jpg" title="Adrienne Johnson " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3617-g2NmJL8QMoc" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/Adrienne%20Johnson.jpg?itok=rhn1JGTh" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>The Departmental Citation Winner for 2009, Adrienne recently completed her PhD in the Modern Thought and Literature program at Stanford.  Titled <em>Diet and the Disease of Civilization, 1977-2008</em>, Adrienne's dissertation analyzes how instructional texts — diet books, nutrition policy, medical research — have measured civilization by the human costs of social progress.  Other academic publications include articles on competitive eating, Paleo diet mythologies, dude ranches, locavorism, and grocery store couponing. She also writes for popular, non-academic audiences in BuzzFeed Food and <em>Gastronomica</em>.</p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->
	<div class="clear"></div>

					<div class="brand grid_9 clearfix"><div id="sm-uc-logo" style="float:right;padding-left:10px;"><a href="http://berkeley.edu" target="blank"><img src="/sites/all/themes/bowtie/images/uc-logo-sm.png" /></a></div>University of California Berkeley<br /><span id="ugis">Office of Undergraduate Interdisciplinary Studies, Undergraduate Division <em>- College of Letters & Science</em></span></div>

		<div id="copyright-wrap">	
			<div class="container_12">
			<div id="copyright" class="grid_12 omega">
			
						
			  <div class="region region-footer-copyright">

	    <div class="clear"></div><div class="clear"></div>    <div class="clear"></div><div class="clear"></div>

	
			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Jessica Gresham </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-d0db0f3af31e4ed44a201a7a80010452">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    &quot;The Female Shape of Jazz&quot;  </h3>  
          <div class="thesis-image"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/gresham%20cover.jpg" title="Jessica Gresham " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3618-k0VPqoaCs8k" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/medium/public/gresham%20cover.jpg?itok=jNvUKyPJ" width="180" height="220" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>The importance of women in jazz has been a severely neglected topic, despite active female participation throughout the genre's history.  To examine this, Jessica Gresham's honors thesis underscores the importance of African American female instrumentalists throughout the early developments of jazz. Using Mary Lou Williams as an archetype, Jessica traces both music and event histories from blues up to the evolution of jazz fusion in the 1970s.  The primary sources consist of original music recordings of the women examined, deconstructing them within a historical context. Combining both a music and event history—as well as personal event history of the artists mentioned—the combination of sources and insight reveal the historical and musical importance of African American female instrumentalists in jazz.</p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    Twentieth Century American Culture  </h3>  
          <p>American Studies 110: The History, Politics, and Landscape of Consumer Society</p>
<p>African American Studies 142AC: Race and American Film</p>
<p>Film 123: 1950s Film and Propaganda</p>
<p>Australian Studies: Australia and America</p>
<p>Letters and Science 180C: Social and Behavioral Science</p>
<p>Sociology 125: Urban Sociology</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Jessica Gresham</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Jessica%20Gresham.jpg" title="Jessica Gresham " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3618-k0VPqoaCs8k" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/Jessica%20Gresham.jpg?itok=joiT2iyM" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>Jessica graduated with honors in 2009, and she currently works as a Veterinary Assistant at the San Francisco SPCA.</p>
    </div>
    </div>

			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Josh Begley </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-855db09f131a293757f44151e2f848ea">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    &quot;Color-Blind Jim Crow: Common Sense in an Age of &#039;Racism without Racists&#039;&quot;  </h3>  
          <div class="thesis-image"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/begley%20thesis%20cover.png" title="Josh Begley " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3619-awOxfwotM8I" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/medium/public/begley%20thesis%20cover.png?itok=Dssght_M" width="170" height="220" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p><em>Color-Blind Jim Crow</em> is an exploration of race, identity, and narrative in the post-World War II United States. Oscillating between legal scholarship and family history, Begley takes the reader through the series of Supreme Court decisions that opens the door for what Eduardo Bonilla-Silva calls ‘color-blind racism.’  From the 'prerequisite cases' of US naturalization law to contemporary school desegregation suits, Begley considers the role a 'consensus memory' of the Civil Rights Movement plays in propagating a particular definition of racism -- one that maintains an individual, psychological, and often transactional focus. Ultimately, Begley asks: how might we destabilize color-blind racism and its central ideological frames? Employing the methodology of storytelling, he argues that it is important to highlight 'race-neutral' public policies in the Jim Crow South to work toward this aim.</p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    Race, Identity, and Narrative in the U.S.  </h3>  
          <p>African American Studies 112B: Political and Economic Development in the Third World</p>
<p>African American Studies 116: Slavery and African American Life before 1865</p>
<p>African American Studies 160: African Literatures</p>
<p>American Studies H110 : Honors Seminar on American National Character</p>
<p>English 133T: Topics in African American Literature and Culture: Toni Morrison</p>
<p>Ethnic Studies 130AC: The Making of Multicultural America: A Comparative Historical Perspective</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Josh Begley</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/Josh%20Begley.jpg" title="Josh Begley " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3619-awOxfwotM8I" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/Josh%20Begley.jpg?itok=LGsjn-w1" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <div>Josh Begley is a data artist and web developer based in Brooklyn, New York. He is the creator of Metadata+, an iPhone app that tracks U.S. drone strikes. His work has appeared in <em>Wired</em>, <em>The New York Times</em>, <em>NPR</em>, <em>The Atlantic</em>, <em>The Guardian</em>, <em>New York Magazine</em>, and at the New Museum of Contemporary Art. </div>
<div> </div>
<div>A graduate of NYU's Tisch School of the Arts, Josh currently works at <em>The Intercept</em>, a publication of First Look Media. See more at <a href="http://joshbegley.com">joshbegley.com</a></div>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->

		</div>

	<!-- Breadcrumb -->
	<!--<div id="breadcrumb-wrap" class="grid_12"><p id="breadcrumbs">You are here: &nbsp; <a href="/">Home</a> &nbsp; &#62;  &nbsp; <a href="/about-major" title="">Major</a> &nbsp; &#62;  &nbsp; <a href="/graduates">Graduate Profiles</a></p></div>-->

	    <div class="clear"></div><div class="clear"></div>    <div class="clear"></div><div class="clear"></div>

	
			<div id="post-content-wrap" class="grid_12"> 
			<h2 class="inner-title">Sonja Carlson </h2>     			
			  <div id="content" >
			  
			    <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system"><div class="widget bottom"><div class="view view-graduates view-id-graduates view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-a188d2c686c104eddca4354e74bc2968">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="clearfix">
      
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Thesis - </strong>    The Making of an American Girl: Perspectives of Race and Class in the Literature of The American Girl Collection  </h3>  
          <p>Sonja’s honors thesis unpacks the cultural work of American Girl’s products by looking at the dolls, books, and accessories as tools of childhood education.  The histories presented by American Girl characters are often a young girl’s first foray into American history, giving great power to the stories.  Many critics of American Girl question whether or not the narratives are accurate, disregarding that history is a series of ideologies and perspectives retold as truth.  American history is regularly told from a white and upper-class perspective, disregarding the experiences of others.  The characters of American Girl and their stories tackle gender, race, and class conflicts throughout American history but rarely present histories different from the normatively white cultural readings of history present in textbooks.  When the history is presented from a Black or Latino standpoint, the American-ness of the character is questioned, signaling a division in the message and cultural work being done by the narrative.  American Girl’s products reinforce the normative white values instead of pushing boundaries and urging young and impressionable girls to explore new perspectives and question what they have been taught as fact.  The first chapter discussed the relationship between dolls, books, and play, giving an understanding of how dolls and doll-play help form understandings of what it means to be young, female, and American.  Three character case studies followed, with each focusing on how class and race are constructed within the character’s six-book series.  The final chapter explored how education and the historical characters were reconsidered under Mattel’s ownership beginning in 1998.</p>
<p></p>
    
  <h3 class="title">    <strong>Area of Concentration - </strong>    American Popular Culture  </h3>  
          <p>History 124B: The United States from World War II to the Vietnam Era</p>
<p>African American Studies 142AC: Race and American Film</p>
<p>Media Studies 101: Visual Communications</p>
<p>American Studies 101AC: World War II</p>
<p>American Studies 101: The Birth of Consumerism</p>
<p>American Studies H110: The New Literary History of America</p>
    
          <h3 class="title">Sonja Carlson</h3>    
          <div class="field-content image-people grid_2"><a href="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/sonja%20carlson.jpg" title="Sonja Carlson " class="colorbox" data-colorbox-gallery="gallery-node-3646-e1YIDaCM3mY" data-cbox-img-attrs="{&quot;title&quot;: &quot;&quot;, &quot;alt&quot;: &quot;&quot;}"><img src="http://as.ugis.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/people/public/sonja%20carlson.jpg?itok=frmimBR6" width="125" height="155" alt="" title="" /></a></div>    
          <p>Immediately following graduation, Sonja moved from Berkeley to Los Angeles and began working as an administrator at a small independent elementary school.  For two years, she led the after school enrichment program and managed the school’s internal and external communications.  Sonja’s duties increasingly involved working in the admissions office, assisting with prospective parent communications, event coordination, and the collection of admissions data and materials.  Beginning in July 2016, she transitioned from the enrichment coordinator position to the full-time admissions and communications assistant.  Sonja is currently applying to graduate programs in library science and archival studies.</p>
    </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div></div><div class="clear"></div></div>  </div>
			  </div>
		  </div>
		</div> <!-- end #body-wrap .container_12 -->

<body class="html not-front not-logged-in no-sidebars page-graduates" >
  <div id="skip-link">
    <a href="#main-content" class="element-invisible element-focusable">Skip to main content</a>

	<div id="top-bg"></div>
	<div class="container_12" id="header" >
